patrick—I said, "In half an hour"—I had an appointment with him in the City—he deals very largely with me for frames—his pictures always come to

my place—he said, "I will send it round in a case; it is not far off; but do not mention my name to Mr. Fitzpatrick"—he said that he was very much pressed for money, and would part with it at a sacrifice, and he should not like any one to know the price he sold it at—I went into the City direct, and afterwards found this picture left at my place (produced)—it has "John Linnell" on it—it is exactly in the same state as when it was brought to me, and is in the same frame—it was inclosed in a rough case—Mr. Fitzpatrick came home with me—he opened the case, and asked me that I thought of the picture—I said I thought it was a great deal of money for so small a picture—Closs had told me to get him 135 guineas for it, and I asked 160l.—I told Mr. Fitzpatrick that a party had brought the picture to me, and that it was the one he had seen at Mr. Smart's—he said, "Yes, it is," and asked me if I thought there was any doubt about it being genuine, and he took it up, and rubbed the name—I told him that I was not a sufficient judge to give an opinion on it, never having had one in my possession, and I thought he had better go to Mr. Linnell before he bought it—I told him that the person was pressed for money, and that it was con
siderably less than Mr. Smart had sold it to him for; and Mr. Fitzpatrick agreed to buy it if it was genuine—I told him that I believed it was genuine, from what I was told—he said that it was too far to go to Mr. Linnell's, as he should lose the train—I then told him to go and ask Mr. Smart, as the picture was painted for him—he said, "I will give 110l. for it, and will go to Mr. Smart"—he went away, returned again, and said, "It is all right; Mr. Smart says it is the picture"—during his absence, I went and saw Closs, and told him that I could not get him what he wanted—he said, "If you bring me 120l. I will give you 10l.;" and when I came back, Mr. Fitzpatrick said, "Well, I will give you 130l. "—he went away with the picture, and gave me a cheque for 24l., and two bills of exchange, making altogether 130l—he told me distinctly to ask Mr. Closs about it being genuine, and if I could get a warranty I was to do so—I handed the cheque and two bills to Closs, and asked him if he would give me a receipt or war
ranty—he said that Mr. Fitzpatrick had been to Mr. Smart's, aha he would sooner have given him 5l. than he should have done so, and that Mr. Smart had said that it was genuine, and what more did he want—I said, "As you ay it is so, that is sufficient.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. How much did you get from Mr. Fitzpatrick for the picture? A. 135l. Closs was to give me 10l. if I sold it, but I should get more if I could, and I did so—if I had got 160l. for it, I should not have given the difference to him, I should have kept all over that—I was not to receive a commission, and he did not ask me what I had got, and I did not tell him—I told him I had got 120l. for it—I afterwards told him I had got 10l. more; that was before the matter was before the Magistrate—the difference between what I accounted for and what I put in my pocket I handed over to Mr. Fitzpatrick; I never gave it to Closs—no one was present at the interview between Closs and me; it Was in my front shop—when I spoke to Closs about the warranty, I had the money in my hand—I did not ask him to give a warranty at the time I went and told him that Mr. Fitzpatrick would only give 110l.—Mr. Fitzpatrick had not said before he went to Mr. Smart's that he must have a warranty from the party, nor did he ask me to get one art that time—he did not ask me to get him a warranty to save him the trouble of going to Mr. Linnell's or Mr. Smart's, nor did he do so when I returned from Closs—when Mr. Fitz
patrick was in a cab going away with the picture, he said that he was

satisfied that it was the picture, but if I could get a warranty I was to do so, and I was not to part with the bills unless Closs would say positively that it was the genuine picture by Linnell—I had not mentioned Closs's name but Mr. Fitzpatrick knew who it was, because he said, "It is a tall gentle-man with a moustache;" and I said, "I will not say that it is not"—Closs said, "If he is not satisfied he can have his money back, for I lose 40l. by it."

MR. METCALFE. Q. Is Mr. Fitzpatrick a regular customer of yours? A. Yes—I do not believe Closs knew him—I took back a 15l. bill, and handed over to Gloss a cheque for 25l., a bill for 40l., and a bill for 50l., making 115l.—I subsequently received from Closs 5l. as part of my 10l.—the bill for 15l. I kept in my hands some time—as soon as I found that only a copy had been sold, I returned the money, so that I lost everything—I saw Closs, and told him that he had acted in a very disgraceful way—I then found that the original picture was sold the same day to Mr. Closs at Mr. Lloyd's—the 40l. bill was left with my wife—I went to Mr. Smart; he was takes into custody and discharged by the Magistrate; the defendant was bound over in his own recognizances to appear here.

LOUISA ADAMS . I am the wife of the last witness—on 23rd or 24th July, the defendant came and asked if Mr. Adams was within; I said, "He is not;" he said, "I have brought this picture round for a gentleman to look at"—I did not see if it was in a case—he said, "Do you know who I am?"—I said, "No"—he said, "My name is Closs, and if Mr. Adams comes in do not mention my name in the presence of the gentleman who he is going to show the picture to"—he told me to be sure to take it up stairs, for it was a very valuable painting, and I was not to allow any one to see it—my husband came in two or three minutes, and they unscrewed the case and took the picture out—this is it.

HENRY FITZPATRICK . I am a carver and gilder. On, I think, 22nd July, I was at Mr. Smart's shop, in Titchborne Street, and saw a picture by Linnell; he asked 200l. for it, and I would not buy it—I have since ascertained that it was the genuine picture—on the 24th I went to Mr. Adams, and he told me he had got the picture in his shop for sale that was at Mr. Smart's; or, "I have got the picture by Linnell"—this is the picture that he then showed me—he told me that a gentleman had left it with him who wanted money for a bill, and who did not want his name mentioned at all—I said, "Did the gentleman say that it was the picture I saw at Mr. Smart's?"—he said, "Yes"—I asked him the price of it—he first said 140l.—I desired him to go to the gentleman and inquire the lowest price he would take for it, if it was the picture I had seen at Mr. Smart's—he came back, and we agreed on 130l.—I then asked if the gentleman would give a warranty with it—he said, that the gentleman would not have his name mentioned in the matter at all—I said, that I should take the picture to Smart's, and if he assured me that it was the picture painted for him by Mr. Linnell, I should be satisfied without a warranty—I went the same day to Mr. Smart's, but he was not at home, it being 7 o'clock; he had gone to Ham
mersmith, where he lives—I went next morning and produced the picture, to him; he looked at it, and I held it in the light at the door for him to see and asked him how it was that the gentleman did not come forward, and how he got it—he said that he got it on a bill for 200l.—I asked him if it was a good bill; he said that he thought it was—I held the picture to him, and he said that there was no doubt of it being a genuine picture—it was the copy—I went back and told Mr. Adams that I was perfectly satisfied, having known Mr. Smart a long time—I bought the picture, but told Mr.

Adams not to give up the cheque and bills till I told him—at the time I parted with my money, I believed it was a picture by Linnell—the name on it is almost a warranty—I knew him to be an artist of eminence.

Cross-examined. Q. The copy is so like the original that you would not like to swear which is the original and which is the copy? A. Yes, I can, having seen it at Mr. Smart's house, and from seeing his picture I should have known—I believe artists do copy their works, so as to produce a duplicate—I should not have been satisfied unless I had gone to Mr. Smart; I doubted the genuineness of it—I do not think I should have parted with my money from anything Adams said to me—when Mr. Smart told me that there was no doubt about it, I was satisfied—I had given Mr. Adams the money on the 24th, but told him to retain it—I did not consider my purchase complete until I had satisfied myself that my purchase was genuine—I wrote Adams a warranty, and told him if he could not get it signed, to get him to state that it was a picture by Linnell—he never, gave that to me signed—Adams told me he was sure he would not sign it, because he would not give his name—it is not usual to get a warranty in buying original pictures; we never buy any except of men of character—I generally buy of the artist.

MR. ORRIDGE. Q. An invoice is generally considered a warranty? A. Yes—I am a carver and gilder—the representations made by Adams that the person he was dealing for had said that it was the same picture I had seen at Mr. Smart's, induced me to deal for it, and from it being the same looking picture.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. If Mr. Smart had told you that it was not the same picture, would you have parted with your money? A. Certainly not—I should have endeavoured to get back the money from Adams, if Mr. Smart had told me that it was not genuine.

COURT. Q. Was Adams at liberty to go and pay the money immediately you gave it into his hands? A. No—I gave him the money, and then went to Mr. Smart's, but he was not at home, and I returned to Mr. Adams and told him not to part with the money till the following day—on the follow
ing day I called, and told him that I had seen Mr. Smart, who had satisfied me that it was the picture which he bought of Mr. Linnell, and for which be gave 175l.—the name of the canvas maker is Reeves, of Tottenham Court Road.
(THE COURT. considered that the Counts for false pretences entirey failed).

SAMUEL BOYDELL . I am a solicitor, No. 41, Queen Street, Bloomsbury. I produce a bill for 40l., dated 24th July, drawn by Joseph Truley, and ac
cepted by Henry Fitzpatrick; endorsed "Joseph Truley, Thomas Closs"—I received it from Adams.

JAMES LLOYD . I am a partner in the firm of Lloyd Brothers, of Grace-church-street. On 24th July we purchased of Closs a picture by Linnell—this is it (The original), it is in the same frame, and the canvas maker is Reeves—we afterwards sold it—the value of the copy, two weeks' work at 2l. a week, with 2l. for the frame, would be 6l.

JOHN LINNELL . I am an artist, and live at Red Hill, near Reigate. I believe I painted this picture for Mr. Smart, in Dec., 1856, and finished it in Feb. 1857—I certainly did not paint the other—I did not paint my name on anybody else's picture.
FRANCIS LUSLEY . I am foreman to Mr. Rought, picture dealer, of Regent Street—he bought the original picture of Mr. Lloyd, in this frame, but it is not the frame we sold it in.

GUILTY on all the Counts except the first .—
Judgment Respited.

1110.
WILLIAM KETCH (55),
Unlawfully assaulting
William Shorety, with intent, etc.

div0.p: OLD COURT.—Tuesday, November 3rd, 1857.

PRESENT—Sir
GEORGE CARROLL . Knt., Ald.; Sir
JOHN MUSGROVE ., Bart., Ald.; Mr. RECORDER.; and Mr. Ald. GABRIEL.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Fifth Jury.

div1.p:
1111.
JOHN BENTLEY (22) was indicted
for a rape upon
Sarah Catherine Harding.
MR. SLEIGH. conducted the Prosecution, and MR. METCALFE. the Defence.
NOT GUILTY .

1112.
JAMES BUTLER (21),
ANN SCANLAN (17),
MARY ANN MOODY (17), and
JOHANNA SMART (15),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
William Nelson, and stealing 4 pairs of boots and other articles, value 36s., his property.
MESSRS. METCALFE. and SHARPE. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM WHITLEY . (Policeman, D 91). On the morning of 6th Oct., I was on duty in Northumberland Street, New Road. I met the four pri
soners and another—I watched them, and saw them stop opposite the pro
secutor's shop—I ran round into Nottingham Street, which leads out of Northumberland Street, and saw the male prisoner with his hand in the prosecutor's shop window—I saw him take out boots and shoes, and hand them to the three female prisoners—they saw me, and they all ran away—I ran after them, and captured Butler about thirty yards from the window—I found on him a pair of Wellington boots; he was carrying them on or under his arm—the females ran away—I saw each of them drop boots and shoes and lasts as they ran—I told Butler, when I took him, that it was for breaking into Mr. Nelson's shop—he said if it was not for the drink, it would not have happened—I found the prosecutor's shutter down, and a pane of glass broken—I have no doubt of the identity of either of the three females—I did not take either of them—I knew them before—I was well acquainted with their faces—I saw them standing at the window three or four minutes, and I had seen them all together before that.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. (for Butler). Q. How far were you from Butler when you say you saw him put his. hand into the shop window? A. About fifteen yards—I saw it distinctly—I have not got the boots here that I found on him—the prosecutor saw them before the Magistrate, and they were given up to him by the Magistrate's order.

WILLIAM NELSON . I am a shoemaker, No. 17, Northumberland Street. On the night in question I closed the premises about 11 o'clock, and went to bed about 12 o'clock, after seeing all safe—the shutters were up, and the window closed, it is not made to open—there was no hole or crack in the glass—the policeman called me up about 2 o'clock—he was holding the male prisoner by the collar, and my boots and shoes were lying about the pave
ment—they belong to me—some were in an unfinished state—I made them myself.

WILLIAM HARPER . (Policeman, D 37). On the night of 6th Oct. I was on duty in High Street, Marylebone, and saw Butler, Scanlan, and Moody near the Shepherd and Flock, at the corner of Weymouth Street—I do not know Smart—there was another female and another man with them, but I did not

know them—I afterwards saw the same five persons in High Street, about half past 1 o'clock, going towards the New Road, and about half past 2 or quarter to 3 o'clock, I saw Scanlan and Moody running down Beaumont Street towards Woodstock Street—I stopped them, and asked them where they were running to—they said they were going home—I said, "Where have you been to?"—they said they had been to the play—I think Scanlan said this—I do not think Moody said anything—I said, "You have not been to the play, for I have seen you several times"—about five minutes afterwards. I saw Butler in custody.

WILLIAM BURT . (Policeman, D 192). I was on duty in the New Road, near Northumberland Street. About 2 o'clock on Tuesday morning; I saw the four prisoners and a man walking along opposite Marylebone Church, about three or four minutes'. walk from Mr. Nelson's—I did not see where they went to, I saw them pass on towards Mr. Nelson's—I did not know them before—I am quite sure they are the persons.
Cross-examined. Q. Was Butler very drunk? A. He did not appear so.

WILLIAM HAMMOND . (Policeman, A 573). I took Scanlan into custody, at No. 14, Little Chesterton Street, at 12 o'clock, on the 6th, in a back kitchen—I told her it was for being concerned with James Butler in committing a burglary—she said, "I have been with James Butler all the morning, but I was not with him when he did the job; I left him at 12 o'clock, at the Shepherd and Flock"—I took Moody in Northumberland Street, about 3 o'clock on the 6th, after the others had been before the Magistrate—as soon as she saw me, she ran away—I brought her back, and told her it was no me her running away—I told her what she was charged with—she said she knew nothing about it.

JOSIAH LANE . (Policeman, D 216). About 2 o'clock on Tuesday morning I saw. Smart in Northumberland Street, about four or five yards from Mr. Nelson's shop—she was running away from the shop—I stopped her, and asked what she was running for, so early in the morning—she said she was running away from a cab man—at that time I knew nothing, about the burglary—I let her go—I saw no cabman.
Smart. He never saw me, neither do the other prisoners know me, I was in bed at 11 o'clock.
WILLIAM BURT . re-examined. I took Smart into custody in Marylebone Lane—I asked her what time she got to bed in the morning, she said about 3 o'clock.
Moody's Defence. I am quite innocent of it, I had nothing to do with the robbery, I did not go through the street.
Smart's Defence. I am innocent of it, I have my two sisters to prove I was at home.

MARY SMART . I am the prisoner's sister, and live at No. 26, Henrietta Street My sister lived with me until she was taken up—she slept in the same room—when I came home from Brompton on this night, at half past 10 o'clock, she was in the room, and also in bed before 11—I awoke in the morning at 20 minutes to 7 o'clock, and she was then in the room—she could not have left without my knowing; it—she never did leave the room—I was very restless, having the face ache—I am a servant, I had only left my place the Wednesday before, at No. 21, South Street, Alexander Square—I had been there four months, and before that I was in a place for six months, and before that for ten months—she was taken into custody on the 6th, from my mother's barrow in Marylebone Lane—my mother and father and sister all slept in the same room the night before, and I assure you she never

left the room after half past 10 o'clock—she is not acquainted with the other prisoners—she only came from the country in May—she was at a cotton factory, where she had been sent by a lady—since May she has been in a situation at 1s. a-week in Grosvenor Market, and she had only left there on the Sunday afternoon.

ELLEN CONNOR . I am a sister of Smart. I am married, and live at No. 24, James Street, Oxford Street—I heard of my sister being taken into custody on the Tuesday night—on the Monday I saw her about 6 o'clock in Marylebone Lane, and again about a quarter to 10, when the constables go on night duty, she was at her mother's barrow with the oysters—I went with her home to my mother's, about 10 o'clock, to ask her to let one of my sisters sleep with me, as my husband was going out—I stopped there till just on 11 o'clock, till they were in bed—I went again in the morning, about 7 o'clock, and my sister was just getting up—I went before the Magistrate to tell him this, but they contradicted me, and said I was a bad character.

DENNIS SMART . I am the prisoner's father. On the night before she was taken I was with her at the corner of Marylebone Lane, at half past 10 o'clock—she drove the barrow home and took the tub of oysters up stairs, and went to the Lamb and Flag, at the corner of Henrietta Street, to know what time it was, and it was five minutes to 11 o'clock—I went up to my room, and on the virtue of my oath my daughter was in bed at that time, and did not get up till between 7 and 8 o'clock in the morning.

WILLIAM WHITLEY . re-examined. The prisoner's sisters were before the Magistrate—I have known Smart, by being on duty round there, for five or six months, I should think—I have seen her with a barrow of oysters, mostly with her father and mother.

BUTLER—
GUILTY . **—
Confined Eighteen Months.

MOODY—
GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

SCANLAN—
GUILTY .

SMART—
NOT GUILTY . (Scanlan was further charged with having been before convicted of felony.)

JOHN FRANCIS . (Policeman, D 72). I produce a certificate—("West
minster; Ann Scanlan, Convicted of larceny, March, 1857, Confined Three Months")—I was present at the trial—she is the person.

SCANLAN— GUILTY.—
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: NEW COURT.—Tuesday, November 3rd, 1857.

PRESENT—Sir
GEORGE CARROLL ., Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. HALE.; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Eighth Jury.

div1.p:
1113.
PETER O'BRIEN (29), and
SIMON O'BRIEN (26),
unlawfully and maliciously inflicting on
John Whittaker grievous bodily harm.
MESSRS. BODKIN. and CLERK. conducted the Prosecution.

MAURICE GIBBONS . I am an engineer, and live at Chelsea. On 23rd Aug. I was near Battersea Bridge, on the Chelsea side—I saw the two pri
soners on the bridge—it was about half past 12 o'clock on Saturday night or Sunday morning—I had heard some disturbance which caused me to go on the bridge—when I got on I saw a row—the two prisoners were having some words with some women—I tapped Peter on the shoulder, and said, "Go home, old fellow, don't get yourself into trouble"—I should say there were very nearly twenty persons on the bridge—when I tapped Peter on

the shoulder he gave me a good blow on the face with his fist—I did not bit him again—I said, "Thank you for that"—he then struck me again, and got me against the rails of the bridge—he attempted to throw me over—whether he intended it or not I do not know—I got my legs through the rails—at that time I saw the policeman Whittaker—he came on the bridge and I offered to give Peter O'Brien in charge for assaulting me—the consta
ble replied, he did not see the blow struck, and he could not take him into custody—the constable went away—after I had made the first complaint to the constable Peter O'Brien tried to throw me over the bridge—I called to the constable, and said, "Did you see that?" but he did not answer me—Peter O'Brien then left me, and went on and struck the constable—I can
not My where he struck him—I had quite enough to do to look after myself—Peter O'Brien made some remark to the constable before he struck him—I could not hear what—the constable said to him, "Go home, or I must take you to the station"—it was after he said those words that Peter struck him—I did not see what was the effect of the blow—I saw Simon O'Brien striking the constable—I do not know whether that was before or after Peter struck him—I saw the constable on the ground, and the two prisoners striking him.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Did you not get out of the row as soon as you could? A. Yes; but I was not off the bridge—I was not taking notice of the number of persons who were on the bridge after I got the first blow—when I first spoke to the constable I was on the bridge—there was a good deal of shouting and hallooing, and confusion when the constable came up—I saw him coining up towards the crowd—I did not see him actually walk on the bridge—I was not on the bridge when I first noticed the disturbance—I was standing by the Adam and Eve public house—there were four or five females there—I saw the prisoners taken to the station.

JOHN WHITTAKER . (Policeman, V 303). I was on duty on 23rd Aug., near Battersea Bridge. About a quarter past 12 o'clock I heard A noise—I went on the bridge—a young man spoke to me—I cannot recognise him—he complained of an assault, but I did not interfere as I saw no assault committed—I saw Peter O'Brien clapping his hands together, and calling for any b—rascal to fight him—I desired him to go home quietly, and not be making any disturbance there—he said, "Is it for you that I am to go home? I will go home when I think proper"—he still continued to call for any rascal to fight him—I said it was better for him to go home quietly and not get himself into trouble, or I would be obliged to take him to the station—I did not see Simon at that time—Peter went towards home, and Simon joined him, and I followed in the same direction a few yards—I saw them quietly off the bridge—as I was following them, the young man who had spoken to me asked what was the reason I did not take him in charge, and I was explaining it to him—he asked my number, and said he would report me at the station—while I was talking to him Peter O'Brien turned back and came to me—he said he would not go home without fighting some b—rascal, and on that he struck me—I had not interfered with him in any way, except in saying what I have stated—he struck me on the head, and on the shoulder several blows—one of the women returned with him, and she got behind me, and put her arm round my body—Simon O'Brien came up and struck me several times on the left side of the head and the shoulder—one of those blows knocked me down—I fell against the kerb stone of the bridge—when I was down Peter O'Brien got on the top of me,

and put his hands in my stock—my hat had fallen off—when Peter knelt on me Simon kicked me in the lower part of my stomach at the side while I was lying on the ground—I then became insensible—when I recovered my senses I found a person of the name of Henry near me—soon afterwards two constables of the A division came up—at that time Peter O'Brien had hold with his two hands in my stock—he was shaking my stock, and choking me—I desired him to let go—one of the constables tried to unfasten his hands from my neck, and could not—he then knocked Peter O'Brien down, and by that means his hands got loose—I had got up from the ground, and the two constables assisted me to the station—when the constables had knocked Peter down I found myself up—I was confined to my bed seven or eight weeks—I lost a great quantity of blood by the bowels—that stopped on Sunday week last—I did not know either of the prisoners personally—I might have seen them.

Cross-examined. Q. When your attention was first called to the bridge, was there a great number of persons and great confusion? A. I saw no confusion—only one person spoke to me—I do not think there were so many as thirty persons—there had been persons coming up from the time it occurred till I took them in charge—there were not so many when I first went—Peter O'Brien had hold of my stock—it was a common leather stock which fastens behind with a clasp, something similar to military stocks—I saw two women at first—I saw three afterwards—I gave the prisoners no provocation—I am an Irishman.

THOMAS HENRY . I am a greengrocer at Chelsea; I have a stable close to Battersea Bridge. On Sunday morning, 23rd Aug., I heard some disturbance on the bridge—I went on the bridge and saw the policeman lying on his back on the narrow pavement—Peter O'Brien was kneeling on his stomach, and his hands were in the policeman's stock—I did not see Simon O'Brien then, he was a little way from me—I ran up and said to Peter O'Brien, "Good God! don't kill the constable"—I took hold of his right arm and pulled him from under the man—Peter had still kept hold of his collar—I tried to get the constable on his seat, and his head fell on one side, and I heard a gurgling noise—Peter had still hold of his throat—I tried to get him away, and one of the A. division came up, and he had a scuffle with Peter, and we got the policeman from him—I did not see Simon do anything to him—several of the A. division came up—I got the constable's hat, and put it on and walked away.

Cross-examined. Q. How did the A's release the constable from Peter? A. They had a scuffle—I will not say whether the constable and Peter were both down, but Peter was down I know, and they turned over, and that released his hold—there were a goodish few persons came up.

EDWARD PEARMAN . I am foreman to a butcher in Chelsea. I was standing at the shop door, which is within 200 yards of the bridge—hearing the noise I went on the bridge—I saw Gibbons there—I heard him complain to Whittaker of his not taking somebody into custody—there were several persons there, and the two prisoners—Whittaker said to Gibbons, "I did not see any blow struck, I can't take him"—I heard him say to the prisoners, "You had better go home quietly, and not make any disturbance"—I then saw both the prisoners strike the policeman several times with their fists on his head and shoulders—I went up to them and said, "That is not right, two on to one"—I caught hold of Simon, we had a scuffle, and I got him down, and there held him till the other policemen came up—after I had taken him away, Whittaker and Peter both fell to the ground—I
did not see what Peter did to him when he was on the ground—I was holding the other man—Whittaker's hat was off when he struck him first.

Cross-examined. Q. There were a number of persons; were they shouting out? A. There was a disturbance certainly, for the police to come to the assistance of this man—that was the cry, and when Peter O'Brien was on the policeman, it was to release him—it was about the middle of the bridge.

HENRY STANDAGE . I am a waiter at Cremorne. I was coming by Battersea Bridge from the gardens after having left my work at a quarter past 12 o'clock—I heard a disturbance and cry of "Police!"—I came up and saw Whittaker on the ground—there was a number of persons, and I saw both the prisoners—Peter had got his hands in Whittaker's stock, and was kneeling on him—Simon was scuffling about, and another man got hold of him—Peter was shaking Whittaker up and down on the kerb stone—Mr. Henry said, "Don't kill the man"—he caught hold of his arm, and I caught hold of his arm, and we got him away—he was quite exhausted, quite gone—he could not move for several minutes—I did not see Simon do any thing to the policeman—I was not there in time for that—two of the A's came up, and one of them tried to get Peter away from Whittaker, and they scuffled and fell—Peter hit him as hard as he could, and told him he would serve him the same.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear anything said by either of the prisoners about their wives and families being insulted? A. I heard them say so at the station—I rather think they were the worse for liquor.

JOHN HILLIER . (Policeman, A. 282). In consequence of a cry of "Police!" I went on this night or morning to Battersea Bridge—I found Whittaker there, and Peter O'Brien holding him by the stock—he appeared very nearly strangled, he could scarcely speak—I requested Peter to release his hold—he said, "No, I will choke the b—and throw him over the bridge"—I then threw Peter on the ground, and succeeded in releasing his hold—Whittaker appeared very exhausted; he was obliged to rest on the kerb a few minutes before he could get up—Peter struck me several times and said, "You b—, I will serve you the same"—Simon was lying on the ground—some parties had hold of him—I did not see him do anything.
Cross-examined, Q. Did you take Peter to the station? A. Yes—he said at the station that he and his wife had been insulted by some parties on the bridge.

JOHN CLARK . (Policeman, A. 273). I came on Battersea Bridge that morning—I took Simon O'Brien in custody—there were three civilians with him trying to keep him from making his escape—he said to me, "If so many of you had not come up, I would have killed the b—"—he made several attempts to strike me, but I kept him off with my truncheon.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he do anything at the station? A. He attempted to strike me there, and he kicked me in going into the station—they were both drunk.

FRANCIS GOODRICH . I am a surgeon. I saw Whittaker four or five days after this—I have attended him ever since—he is still under my care—at that time serum and blood was being passed with the urine from the kidneys till about a fortnight ago, and also from the bowels, which indicates great internal injuries—I consider him in a dangerous condition—I think, if he goes on even in the best way that we can expect, he will never be fit for duty again, for any active employment or hard work—blows or kicks on
the abdomen would account for the blood passing from the bowels, and blows on the back for blood passing the other way.

PETER O'BRIEN—
GUILTY .

SIMON O'BRIEN—
GUILTY . *

1114.
SOPHIA WRIGHT (21),
Unlawfully endeavouring to conceal the birth of her child.
NOT GUILTY .

1115.
WILLIAM RYAN ,
Unlawfully assaulting
Thomas Mears.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: OLD COURT.—Wednesday, November 4th, 1857.
PRESENT—Mr. RECORDER.; Mr. Ald. GABRIEL.; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Seventh Jury.

div1.p:
1116.
FREDERICK SPAIN ,
stealing 1 sack of flour, value 2l. 6s.; the goods of
Samuel Prettyman Mumford and others.
MR. HORRY. conducted the Prosecution.

ARTHUR BRAIN . I am delivery man to Mr. Samuel Prettyman Mum
ford, a miller, at Greenwich. On Thursday morning, 17th instant, I de
livered twenty five sacks of flour into a van for Mr. Nunn, a baker in Brewer Street, Somers Town, about 10 o'clock—the sacks were all marked with Mr. Mumford's name—Taylor had charge of the van—I knew the pri
soner—he has sometimes been with the van when a man has not been well—he was not employed by Mr. Mumford, or by me, but by the carmen—he was not in Mr. Mumford's employment at this time.

Cross-examined by MR. T. ATKINSON. Q. I suppose the carmen require extra assistance in getting the sacks out of the van? A. No: that is not allowed—a sack of flour weighs 2 1/2 cwt.—a man can manage that himself—I know that they do sometimes get help—the carman is responsible for the flour.

WILLIAM COOPER . I am in the employment of Mr. Curtis, a cow keeper, at Somers Town, opposite Mr. Nunn's. On Thursday evening, 17th Aug., about 7 o'clock, I saw the prisoner in a van of Mr. Mumford's, helping the man to unload—I saw all the sacks removed but one—I saw the prisoner get out of the van, and draw the horses round into Smith Street, and then he got up into the van again, and covered the sack over—he was then about four houses from Mr. Nunn's—Smith Street is a dark street, with nothing but private houses—after he had covered the sack over, he drew the horses round into Penny Street, by the Independent public house—there were five vans there—I did not follow the van.
Cross-examined. Q. Then you did not see it stop at the public house? A. Yes: all the five vans stopped there, and the carmen all went in—I suppose the prisoner went in also—I did not see him.

HENRY BAILEY . I am in the service of Mr. Ibbetson, a cheesemonger, opposite Mr. Nunn's. On Thursday evening, the 17th, I saw the vans of flour delivered at his shop—I saw the last van at the door—I saw the prisoner partly conceal a bag of flour in the van with the tarpaulin—he then got out of the van, and drew it round into Smith Street. I did not see any more.
NOT GUILTY .

1117.
ELLEN HOGG (28),
Unlawfully concealing the birth of her child.
MR. SHARPE. conducted the Prosecution, and MR. LANGFORD. the Defence.

1118.
CHARLES FOULD, alias De Fleury (34),
Unlawfully obtaining 340l. worth of blankets, the goods of
John Foster Sykes, by false pretences.
MR. SLEIGH. conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN FOSTER SYKES . I am a flannel and blanket merchant, of No. 72, Aldermanbury. The prisoner was introduced to me by a person named Knight, whom I knew something of—I asked him for a reference, and sold him a parcel of goods on credit, amounting to 144l.—he called on me on the 20th of the same month, May, and told me that he expected to haves contract with the French Government for blankets—he had given his name as Fould and Co., No. 3, Cannon Street, and told me that he was related to Monsieur Fould, the Prime Minister of France—he said on the second occasion that he expected to have an order from the French Govern
ment for blankets for the camp at Chalons, and he should have an order for me—I sold him a parcel of goods amounting to 113l.—he called on me again about the first week in June, and said, "I want you to get me some samples of blankets, to see if I can obtain that contract; they are going to be put before the French Government, and I want samples from you as well as from other houses"—I asked him what quantity he should want, and he wrote it on a paper, and gave it to me—I have looked for it, and cannot find it; I believe it has been torn up—I left my books and papers at the office of Mr. Child, the inquiry agent—it was an order for 200 or 300 blankets; fifty pairs of nine-quarters, fifty pairs of ten-quarters mediums, fifty pairs of nine-quarters supers, and fifty pairs of ten-quarters supers—a few days afterwards he called again, and told me that the goods had been placed before the Government, and said, "I have got the contract, and it is for you; you must supply the goods"—I said, "Very well"—the paper was in French, and I did not understand it—it was headed, "Gouvernement de Francais"—he said, "Here is the contract for the French Government"—it was partly printed, and partly written—there was a printed form on one side, and when you turned over the leaf there was the order on the other—it looked like a very large order—I could understand the numbers, but not the writing—there was a column of figures—he said that he wanted 5, 000 pairs a month, or upwards, and a fortnight after every delivery I should receive the money for them—I procured the goods, and then went over and saw him at 3, Cannon Street—it is two or three offices, up three flights of stairs—I told him that a portion of the goods had come up, and said, "Where are they to be sent to"—he said, "Send them into Arnold's, the packers, in Barge Yard: shall I send a cart over, or will you send them?"—I said, "Just as you like"—he said, "Very well, let them lie at your place until I send a cart for them"—a cart arrived, and they were given into the charge of the carman in my presence—that order was not entirely completed—there were 200 pairs in the first lot—I delivered 200 pairs more on 18th June, and on 23rd June 100 pairs large size—he had told me on the 18th or the 23rd that he wanted larger sizes of the same qualities as I had sent in, and gave me an order for 100 pairs, which I got for him—he said something about a better class for the officers—I should not have parted with those goods if I had not believed his statement, that he had an order from the French Government—I last saw him between the 6th and 24th of Aug.—I found him there two or three
times, but not on the last occasion—I did not see him for several weeks, though I made efforts to do so.

Cross-examined by MR. TINDAL ATKINSON. Q. Are you not an agent? A. Yes, for Schofield and Co., of Rochdale—they do not manufacture blankets, only flannels—Knight is a party who was formerly in the employ of Whitesell and Co.—he was my town traveller at this time—the reference the prisoner gave me was to Mullett and Co., of Fenchurch Street—I went there, and was satisfied with what they told me—that was the foundation of my credit with him—I drew on him at first in two bills for 113l. 2s. 2d. and 144l. 4s. 6d.—the 113l. bill was honoured, and the 144l. was not—I never borrowed 20l. of him—I went and got money on account, and gave him an I O U—I suppose that was after I had taken the bills, but it was not before he had got goods worth a great deal more than that from, me—I had got two bills on the 21st—I did not borrow 20l. of him, that I am aware of, on an I O U, on 19th May—I had a paper cancelling all the I O U's, but have torn it up—I should not enter 20l. borrowed in my cash book; I did not ask him to lend me the money; I asked him if he would give me so much on account—there is a small sum on the 20th, of 7l. 10s., for goods supplied to him—I cannot tell the date, or whether I got 5l. on the 29th—I have had several small sums—I could not take upon myself to say that I have not—I may have had money from him on the 29th May—I cannot go into dates—I am not aware that I had money from him when it was not due for goods—I might have had money from him two or three times during a week—he told me that he could not find the I O U's, and gave me a paper cancelling them—they were not given up—they amounted to 100l., a little over or a little under—I cannot say whether I left a blue covered sample book of blankets on 9th June for his inspection—I do recollect the fact of taking it over there, and after it had been there some time I may have seen him on the subject of the purchase of the blankets—I recollect his giving me an order for 200 samples, and 1, 200 pairs at my con
venience—the order for the 1200 pairs was not given to me at the same time—they were ordered perhaps three or four days afterwards—they were to be delivered as soon as possible—I stated, in Mr. Schofield's presence, that I had an interest in the concern—I was not in any way interested as a partner—the 1, 200 blankets were to be paid for, fourteen days after their delivery—this is the order for them (produced)—this large writing is the defendant's—I began to deliver the blankets upon that order on 27th July—I have had several amounts of money on I O U's—on 8th July I went to him and got a settlement—that was nothing further than an I O U—I told him that my friends were anxious for me to get money for them, and that I wanted to balance the account—he said, "Very well, we will go into if"—that was about 5th July, and on 8th July I told him what was due to me—I cannot say what it was, but it was a large amount—he gave me some money on that day, and it was added to the I O U to make up the balance, and I drew on him—I told him that I should draw bills on him—I got bills from him for the balance—I found that, on 8th July the amount he owed me was 518l., after deducting 100l., the amount of I O U's—that did not take in the 113l. which had been met—that was crossed off the two first transactions—we cancelled the I O U's and began with a clean slate—just before 24th July, when the 113l. bill became due, I began to make a little inquiry—I did not make inquiries of his housekeeper—she was brought before me in his presence to say that a party in Manchester, one of my friends, had been making inquiries about him, and I said that the reference

I had had was very satisfactory to me, and it would induce me to trust him to any amount—I have handed Mr. Schofield's account over to him, and he has put it into the hands of his solicitors—I was before the Magistrate at the Mansion House, and was cross-examined by Mr. Sleigh for the prisoner—I did not threaten Mr. Brunell, that if the money was not paid I would prosecute this man—I told him I wanted the money, and if I could not get it by fair means, I must take other means—I have never offered to withdraw this charge if my lawyer's bill was paid, and sufficient given me to pass through the Bankruptcy Court—I said nothing about the Bankruptcy Court—I said something to Mr. Fould's servant, but I was so excited I could scarcely know what I was saying—I saw Mr. Fould under the Mansion House; I had to go out the back way, and he asked if I wanted to speak to him; I said, "No, except to say that I am very sorry indeed to see you placed in this position"—he said, "Well, do not appear against me at the Old Bailey"—I said, "I am bound over in 40l. to appear against you"—he asked me to feel for him and his wife and his two children; I said, "Her's is a position that I should not like to be placed in myself"—he asked me if I would go up to his house and see his wife, and tell her that he was quite well, and pacify her a little—I said, "I do not like going up there, but as it is your wish, I will do so," and I went and told Mrs. Fould what had passed, and that he wished me to withdraw the charge, and if I did and he got his liberty again, I should not lose one farthing, but that I was bound over to appear or forfeit 40l., which I was not in a position to do, and, besides that, there was 20l. solicitor's expenses—I did not say that if that was paid I would withdraw—I was prosecuting the defendant at that time—I find that I have been very wrong in going there, for he has written to his wife, and says that if he is released, he shall come against me for false imprisonment, and I think that is a very nice way of paying me for my kindness—I was not in the habit of going backwards and forwards and lunching with the defendant while this business was going on—I have had wine with him at his office; he has asked me to do so several times—I have, of course, removed from Aldermanbury—he has ruined me, and I have been obliged to give up my place—I have nothing to remove—I have left.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. What is the value of the property which this man has obtained from you, and which you are still a sufferer by? A. 838l. 5s. 4d.—none of those bills which were given to make a clean slate have been paid—when I made inquiries at Mulletts', they said they had known him some months—he told me that I could also inquire at the Unity Bank, but I did not wish to go there—it was he that spoke to me at the Mansion House, from the cell—the cell doors have wires, and I was passing by and he called out to me—he told me in that conversation that he had not had a contract from the French Government, and that if I would not prosecute him, he would get money of his friends and I should not lose one farthing—he had then been fully committed for trial.

COURT. Q. You said on one occasion, that you had received a satisfactory reference and could trust him with 1000l.; what do you mean by saying that you would not have supplied the goods if you had not believed his statement that he had orders from the French Government? A. Well, I should have asked him something further about that—of course I spoke in the same way as Mulletts', the party I got the reference from—the goods only came to about 800l., but then he had given me an order for some 1000 pairs of blankets—if he had ordered them without a reference, of course I must known something further about him, although I said that I would

trust him with 1000l.—I should like to have had another reference first—I did not ask for another reference—I, perhaps, might have trusted him to the extent of 8001. if he had said nothing about the French Government—I do not think I should have trusted him to the extent of 800l. on the reference alone—I should very likely have trusted him to a great extent if he had not said a word about the French Government.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: ESSEX CASES.

div1.p:
1119.
JOHN NASH (27),
Stealing 1 pig, price 30s.; the property of
Thomas Connolly.
MR. M. J. O'CONNELL. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES CONNOLLY . I live at Stratford. On 21st Oct., I had two pigs in my possession—they were my brother's—on that morning, I let the pigs out of the sty about half past 6 o'clock, into the yard—at a quarter to 7, I missed one of them—I went in search of it, but could not find it—I got some information from a neighbour—on the Friday morning following, I went towards Stratford—I saw the prisoner about 100 yards from where I live, driving the pig—there were two or three men with him—I said, "Who owns this pig?"—the prisoner said, "I do"—I asked where he got it from; he said he bought it—I asked who he bought it of; he said, of a man down Stratford—I asked if he knew him; he said he did not—I said, "You will have to find him, for that pig belongs to my brother"—I said I would fetch him, and shut the prisoner and the pig in the Church school room yard.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. How long were you absent? A. About a minute and a half—I found they were gone—I looked for them and found them about three quarters of a mile from where I had left them, going towards Bow—he had the pig tied to a string—I do not know whether he had it tied when I first saw him—I then gave him into custody—he was going in the same direction as when I first saw him, towards where he lives.

THOMAS CONNOLLY . I am a ginger beer maker, and live at Stratford. I had two pigs in my brother's custody—I remember one pig being lost on the 21st Oct.—on the Saturday, I saw it at the station—it has some marks on it by which I know it.

JOSEPH BRYDON . (Policeman, K 157). The prisoner was given into my custody on Friday, the 23rd of Oct.—he was charged with stealing a pig—I asked him how he came with the pig in his possession; he told me he had bought it of a man and paid 25s. for it—I asked if he could give a description of the man—he said, "No," and I took him to the station—the pig was shown on Saturday morning to the last witness, and he claimed it.

(The prisoners statement before the Magistrate was read as follows: "How I got the pig was, my brother-in-law sent for me to know if I had got a place to put the pig in until it was claimed by some one; he told me the pig broke into his place, and broke one of his large geraniums; when I was taking the pig away, I saw Mr. Connolly, and he says, 'Where did you get that pig from;' I says, 'Why?' he says, because the pig belonged to him; I says, I would not give up the pig before I saw my brother-in-law about it; I would not let any one have the pig, and this man took me to the station.")

CAROLINE LEE . I am the wife of James Lee, who lives at Stratford. On Wednesday, 21st Oct., a pig came into my house—I was lighting my fire, and I heard a noise in the front room; I turned round, and saw two pigs there—I drove them out; I had lighted my fire when one came in again, and I drove it out into the back yard—I let it remain until my hus
band caine home—it broke a glass lamp, standing on the table, and a case of stuffed birds—I was trying to drive it out with a broom, when my husband came home I told him a stray pig had come in; he asked me what mischief it had done—I told him; he said, "Let it remain," and he would send to the police station, and give information about it—it was there from the Wednesday until the Friday—on that day the prisoner came for the pig—my husband was not at home, and I gave him the pig to keep until the owner was found; that was the agreement between my husband and him.
COURT. Q. Did he come for it, and drive it away from your premises? A. Yes; he tied a string to its leg, and drove it off—that was, I think, about half past 6 o'clock at night.

Cross-examined by MR. O'CONNELL. Q. How far does the prisoner live from you? A. I do not know the distance—he lives at Bow—I gave him the pig to keep until an owner was found, because we had no place for it—we were afraid we should not be allowed to keep it—he has a different place for keeping it, a field—I did not see him from the time I gave him the pig until I saw him in custody.

JAMES LEE . I live at Stratford, and am foreman in Mr. Burford's manu
factory. I have been there ever since I was nine yean of age—when I came home on the day in question, I asked who broke the case of birds; my wife said a pig came in the place and ran underneath the table, and upset the case—I was very angry, and said I would keep the pig until I found the owner, and would make him pay for it—I asked my lodger to write a letter for me to take to the station house, on the Thursday; he said he would take it; he delayed it—I asked him for it on Friday; he gave it to me, and I took it to the station as soon as I had done work, about 9 o'clock—I went to where my brother-in-law works, and asked him if he would take the pig until I could find an owner, as I had got no place to keep it—he did so—when I went to the station they said they knew nothing about any pig.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did you see the prisoner about taking care of the pig? A. At the wharf, where he was at work—it is about half a mile from my place.
NOT GUILTY .

1120.
HENRY DENBY (26) and
JOHN HOLBROOK (25),
Stealing three curtains, and other goods, the property of
Ann Mary Halwell and
Robert Wright.
MR. HORRY. conducted the Prosecution.

ANN MARY HALWELL . I am cook to Miss Hall, of Leyton. On 30th Sept., I had been washing some articles—I hung them out to dry between 4 and 5 o'clock, in the afternoon, in Miss Hall's drying ground, adjoining the lawn—these (produced) are the things; some are Miss Hall's, some mine, and some the coachman's; some have not been found.

Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Q. When did you miss them? A. At a quarter to 6 o'clock—the church clock was facing me, and I looked at it; it is about four minutes' walk—I do not know how far I walk in that time—it was near the end of September, but I can always see the clock—I know these things belong to Wright, because I have washed for him oc
casionally
for six years; I also helped to make them—I know my own work.

ROBERT WRIGHT . I am coachman to Miss Hall. I saw these things safe at 5 o'clock, on the day in question—I missed them at a quarter to 6 o'clock—the lines had been cut, and taken away—these scarves are mine.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you examined before to-day? A. Yes, at Ilford; there is no mark on the scarves by which I know them—they are exactly like mine—they were found in Mr. Charrington's Park.
JAMES CHOAT . I am a labourer, living at Stratford. On 30th Sept, I saw the prisoners together at Leyton—that was a quarter before 5 o'clock—Denby had a bag with him—there was nothing in it.

Cross-examined. Q. What were you doing? A. I was carrying a pail to fetch water; I spoke to Denby, but he made no answer—I had seen him a great many times—I stopped on the road, and these two went up to
wards Miss Hall's place; I took particular notice of the bag, because it was slung over his shoulder; and Holbrook asked me in the morning, whether I had seen anything him—I had known Holbrook before—I said, at the Police Court, I had known him.

JOHN WILDING . I am an appraiser and house agent, living at Leyton. On 30th Sept., I was standing at my garden gate, near Miss Hall's, about 5 o'clock—a gentleman came, and spoke to me—in consequence of what he said, I looked towards Miss Hall's—I there saw some things on the line, and, in an instant, the things went down, as if the line had been cut; presently, I saw two men come away directly from the spot; they went through the church-yard, towards Leyton—I went up the pathway, towards Miss Hall's drying ground, and saw the two men come through; one had a bag—I know the jacket one had on—the prisoner Denby had on that jacket he has now; Holbrook followed him—I only saw they had a bag with something in it; I then went round the path, towards Leyton, to look for a constable, so as to come round and meet them.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever see Denby before? A. I have seen both of them; all this occurred in a very little while; the nearest man was about two hundred or three hundred yards off; it might not be so far—I did not see them after this until they were in custody at Ilford.

RICHARD NEALE . I am a cow keeper, at Leyton, near to Miss Hall. On 30th Sept., my attention was called to the two prisoners; I had seen them before—Holbrook was pulling the clothes off the line—Denby was kneeling down, putting them in the bag—I was standing at a window—they then went towards Leyton Churchyard—I then gave information to the police.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Denby?. A. Yes; he goes about col
lecting rags and bones—I was not near the last witness, nor did I speak to him—there was a field between me and Miss Hall's, about 200 yards—I am sure Holbrook is the man who was taking the things off the line—I was examined before the Magistrate at Ilford—I could not swear to the man then—I might have seen Holbrook before; Denby I have seen come round for the rags and bones—when before the Magistrate, I did not "only believe" that Holbrook was the man who was taking the clothes off the line—it might be that I never saw him before, but I know him—he was the smaller man of the two—I did not see him afterwards until he was in cu
tody at Ilford.
THOMAS PORTER . I am a coal dealer, living at Stratford. On 30th Sept. I was driving a horse and van near the Blackbird public house, at Leyton;

I was driving towards Stratford—I saw Holbrook on the road—he came up to me—I stopped the horse—he then stepped back, and beckoned the other prisoner—he came up in a few minutes with the bag—they put the bag in the waggon, got up, and rode as far as the Castle inn, at Stratford—they there got down and walked away.

Cross-examined. Q. At the time Holbrook came up, did you notice the other man? A. No, I did not for the moment—Denby was carrying the bag—there was another man got into the waggon at the same time—he was carrying a basket of china, and the prisoners helped to lift it.

GEORGE HUNTER . (Policeman, N 357). On 2nd Oct. I took Holbrook into custody, in East Street, Stratford. I told him it was for a robbery—he asked me where it was, and I told him at Leyton, on Wednesday—he said, "I was not there on Wednesday"—I then took him to the Waltham
stow station.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you tell him it was for stealing linen in the first instance? A. I did not; I told him it was for a robbery at Leyton, at Miss Hall's—where I took him was about two miles from Leyton.

CHARLES CARPENTER . (Policeman, N 477). I found the prisoner Denby at Stratford—I asked him whew he was on Wednesday last—he said, "I was at home"—I said, "Be careful; I am a police constable; I am going to take him into custody"—he said, "What for?"—I told him for a robbery of wet linen at Leyton—he said, "I was at home on Wednesday"—he afterwards said, "I was at Leyton on Saturday last"—after that, he said he was there on Tuesday, but was at home Wednesday and Thursday—I asked him who was with him—he said, "Chitty Holbrook."
ANN MARY HALWELL . re-examined. This (produced) is the sort of line on which the things were; the other part is left on the post.

ROBERT WRIGHT . re-examined. I found these things in Mr. Charrington's park, about 8 o'clock, on 1st Oct.—the gardener told me of them, and found them just inside the park, near the walk through the churchyard—they are not all the things that were lost.

DENBY—
GUILTY .

HOLBROOK—
GUILTY .
(The prisoners were further charged with having been before convicted).

JOSEPH BENTON . (Policeman, K 381) I produce the certificate—(one of these certified the conviction of Henry Revell in May, 1848, of Larceny; and the other, the conviction of John Holbrook, of Larceny)—I was present at the trial of Henry Revell—Denby is the person so described—he has been getting an honest living since 1848—Holbrook is the person mentioned in the second certificate.

DENBY— GUILTY.—
Confined Nine Months.

HOLBROOK— GUILTY.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1121.
JOHN MURRAY (32),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1122.
EDWARD HEWLINGS (38),
Stealing 5l.; also, embezzling 15l.; the moneys of
William Henry Dean, his master; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

div0.p: KENT CASES.

div1.p:
1123.
JOHN BUTLER (16) and
JOHN CROWLEY (16),
Stealing 7 purses, value 5s.; the goods of
Thomas Robinson: Butler having been before convicted: to which

BUTLER
PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Two Years.

CROWLEY
PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1124.
WILLIAM JAMES (17) and
GEORGE SHEFFARD (14)
Stealing 1 shawl, value 5l.; the goods of
Alfred George Kennedy.
MR. HORRY. conducted the Prosecution.

ABRAHAM HAMMOND . I am in the service of Alfred George Kennedy, of Lime Grove, Lewisham. On 5th Oct., between 10 and 11 o'clock, I was at work in the garden—from information I received, I went round to the front of the house—the front door was open—it was not open when I left it—I missed this scarf shawl from the passage (produced)—I saw some footmarks on a stone against the front door—they were not very large; like the toes—I had last seen the scarf hanging up in the hall about half an hour before—I saw two lads walking, dressed in black coats and caps—I only saw their backs—I went after them, and they ran away directly they saw me—they were a long way before me, and I lost sight of them—the prisoners are about the height of the boys I saw—I found a police officer, and told him—we went to Lewisham Bridge; near Hanover Street we met two boys—they were dressed like those I had seen in the field—they both turned round, and ran away—the officer ran after them, and we took them—I am sure the prisoners are the same persons—James said he would not go—he got hold of the policeman's leg, and threw him down—the policeman had hold of the other one—James got his coat torn down the back—they both got away—I did not see them again until they were in custody—the next morning I went into the field, and found this scarf shawl about 150 yards to the left, away from the direction in which the boys ran—it was under a hedge in a ditch—it was not in a place where people often walk—I believe there was no footpath there—it would take two or three minutes to go from the street door to where I found the scarf—when I looked out in that direction I saw two persons; I was not able to see them until they got some distance up the field, so as to be in a straight line—I could not see the shawl from the house, because of the ditch.

ELIZA COPE . I am servant to Mr. Phillips, who lives next door to Mr. Kennedy's. On 5th Oct., between 10 and 11 o'clock in the morning, I was up stairs, in the front of the house—I saw the two prisoners—they came through the Grove, from the direction of Mr. Kennedy's house—I saw them about 10 o'clock, first, coming up the Grove; they passed our door—I saw them about five or ten minutes afterwards; they then went into the fields—I saw one lying down, and the other leaning against a post—after a short time they went away towards Lewisham; James walked first, and the other walked behind him—in consequence of what I saw, I spoke to Hammond—he went into the fields where the prisoners were seen going—I know where the scarf was found—Hammond pointed it out—I saw the prisoners near there—one of them was stooping while there.
James. Q. When you saw me in the field I was leaning against the post,
was I not? A. Yes—you were doing nothing—you had something beneath your coat, under the left arm.
James. I had a nose-bag.
COURT. Q. When you first saw them, were they very near? A. Yes; they were close under my face—I was up stairs—I am sure these are the persons who were standing where the shawl was found.

JOHN TUFFERY . (Policeman, R 155). On 5th Oct. I was on duty at Lewisham—Hammond came to me—I accompanied him to Lewisham Bridge—we there met the prisoners—they turned round, and ran down Hanover Street—I overtook them—when I caught them, James asked what I wanted with him—I had them both, one in each hand—I told them they were charged with stealing a shawl at Lewisham—James said he had not been there—Sheffard stooped down, caught hold of my legs, and threw me down—James pushed my shoulders—I let Sheffard go—he went off, hat returned just as I was in the act of getting up, and seized James—his coat was torn, and he slipped away—when I charged them, they both said they had not been at Lewisham that morning—I afterwards went to the field, and Hammond pointed out where the scarf was found—there is no thoroughfare through the fields.

ALFRED JOHN CROUCH . (Policeman, R 92). On 13th Oct I was on duty at Greenwich police station—the prisoner James came to the door of the station, and said very abruptly, "What is it you want me for?"—I asked him to be kind enough to step in, and I would show him—he came in, and I produced the printed information—I asked him if he could read—he could not, and I read it to him—I told him I should take him into custody, as he was charged with stealing, in the company of George Sheflard, a scarf shawl—he said that he knew nothing about it, he had not been there at all—I asked him why he ran away from the constable when he was taken into custody—he said that he did not go away from him, but he let him go—I asked him where he had been in the interval—he said at Croydon Pair—I then locked him up—about 3 o'clock on the same day I went to Lewisham, to apprise the parties that James was in custody—when I came back, Sheffard was waiting at the station—he asked me what I wanted him for—I produced to him the printed information, and he read it—he said that he knew nothing at all about it: he was not at Lewisham—I asked him why he ran away from the constable, and he also said he did not run away, but that he let him go—he said he had been at work at different places—I then locked him up.

James's Defence. I was going up the Grove to look after my father's mules; I had a nose bag under my arm; I saw Sheffard, and I asked him to come with me, and look after the mules; I had found them there before; Sheffard sat down to do something to his shoe; I walked straight up the fields; I then went to Green, to go down to Lewisham; I never had or saw the shawl before.
Sheffard's Defence. I was at work all the week for Mr. Coleman, in the brickfields; but, being wet that day, I could do no work; James came up, and I went with him; I never saw the shawl.

JAMES—
GUILTY . **—
Confined Two Years.

SHEFFARD—
GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

div0.p: SURREY CASES.
Before Lord Chief Baron Pollock (with Mr. Baron Martin and Mr. Justice Willes).

div1.p:
1125.
ANTONIO DE SALVI (29) was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Robert Henderson Robertson. (See page 568.)
MESSRS. BODKIN. and CLERK. conducted the Prosecution.
(On the part of the prisoner, a plea of autrefois acquit was pleaded at the last Session, to which the Crown demurred, and the matter now came on for argument.)

MR. BODKIN. submitted that the plea was bad in point of law, as it did not aver that the crime with which the prisoner was now charged was identical with that upon which he had been previously tried; it only alleged that the cause of death was the same, which would not support the plea. It was not a necessary ingredient in murder that there should be an intent to commit that offence; murder might be committed where it was manifest the party had no such intention, as in resisting a lawful apprehension, where the only intention might be to escape, or in administering drugs to procure abortion; yet in such cases, if death ensued, the crime would be murder; and an acquittal, on a charge of wounding with intent to murder, would be no answer, in the form of the present plea, to that charge.

MR. EDWIN JAMES ., Q. C., in support of the plea, contended that the wounding with intent to murder, charged in the first Count of the former indictment, and of which the prisoner was acquitted, was in effect the same accusation as the present. It was not disputed that it arose out of the same transaction and from the same wounding. It was clearly laid dawn in Chitty's Treatise on the Criminal Law, p. 455, that it was not in all cases necessary that the two charges should be precisely the same in degree; it was sufficient that an acquittal of one would show that the defendant could not be guilty of the other. The present case fell within that principle; the wounding was the Same, the penalty was the same, death in either case. The mere fact of the death of the party wounded did not affect the question; for, although not the ordinary course, there was no reason why, if the death had occurred at the time, the prisoner should not have been tried for the very offence of wounding with intent to murder, of which he had been acquitted; nor would it have been any answer to such a proceeding to say that, because the man was dead, therefore the prisoner could not be tried on such a charge. It was analogous to the case of a party acquitted of a common assault, which he might plead in bar to any future indictment for a felonious assault, there being but one assault, and the felonious intention and the transaction being identical with the assault of which there had been a previous acquittal. As an authority for this proposition, see the Crown v. Robinson, 5 Deas and Anderson's Reports, 26l. also 5 Law Chronicle, Regina v. Walker, 2 Moody and Robinson, 446. upon these and other authorities (to be referred to), he contended that this case came within that principle of the law which declared that no man's life should be placed in jeopardy twice for the same offence.

Upon MR. SERJEANT PARRY. proceeding to address the Court on the same side, the LORD CHIEF BARON. expressed the opinion of the Court that only one Counsel could be heard. After some discussion, it was arranged that Mr. M'Mahon should conclude the argument commenced by Mr. James; but the COURT. desired that, in permitting this course, under the present circumstance,

p.hi: no precedent should be drawn from it that more than one Counsel had a right to be heard.

div1.p:
MR. M'MAHON. apprehended that the Court would consider the case upon the record only, abstractedly of the facts. The plea stated that the prisoner was, upon a former occasion, indicted for cutting and wounding, with intent to murder, and that he was acquitted of that offence; the plea did not allude to any second Count, nor did the Crown reply that Count; he was therefore clearly acquitted of the wounding which caused the death, and the Court could take no notice of the grounds, of that acquittal; the acquittal was of the whole offence, of everything essential to be proved against him; for if it had been possible, on the facts, to convict of an unlawful wounding, the Statute enabled the Jury so to do. As to the general rule, that a party cannot be tried twice for the same offence, the learned Counsel referred to Blackstone, 2 Hale's Pleas, ch. 35 and 36; 4th Cooke, p. 40, (Darley's case), Hudson and Lee; Yaux's case, Holcroft's case Sparrow's case; 5 Cooke, p. 6l. As to case of pardon, he referred to Hale's Pleas, 426; Plowden, 401, (Cole's case); Cooper v the Hundred of Basingstoke; 7 Modern Reports; also, 2 Salkeld, 614; Holt's Reports, 638; and 2nd Raymond, 826, Hales and Pettit; Plowden, 262; Cole's case, Nicol's case; Foster's Reports, 64; and Rex v. Jenning, Russell and Ryan, 388. From these cases he urged that, if the Crown, instead of prematurely proceeding to trial before the death, had granted a general pardon of all felonies and offences, it was quite clear that the prisoner could not have been afterwards tried for the murder, and the case was exactly the same upon pardon, punish
ment, or acquittal. The case of Rex v. Vandercourt and Abbott, 2 East, 519, and Leech's Crown Law, 316, was very much in point; to an indictment for burglary, with intent to steal, was pleaded a former acquittal of burglary and stealing; but as, upon the first indictment, there was no proof of stealing it was held to be no bar to the second. This established the principle that unless the first indictment were such as the prisoner might have been convicted upon by proof of the facts contained in the second, an acquittal on the first indictment could be no bar to the second; and this principle was a very striking test to apply to the present case. He therefore submitted, as well upon the general principle as upon the authorities referred to, that, first, upon the ground of the pleadings, the prisoner had substantially been acquitted of this offence; and, secondly, if the pleadings were to be amended, and the Crown permitted to reply the conviction on the second Count, that, then the prisoner would be punished twice for the same offence.

p.hi: The Counsel for the Crown were not called upon to reply.

div1.p: THE LORD CHIEF BARON . "I believe we are all of opinion that this is not a good plea. The prisoner is, on the present occasion, indicted for murder, and murder may be committed without any intent to kill. If a man intends to maim, and causes death, and it can be made out most distinctly that he did not mean to kill, yet if he does those acts and use those means for the purpose of accomplishing that limited object, and they are calculated to produce death and death ensues, by the law of England that is murder, although the man did not mean to kill. On the former occasion the prisoner was charged with wounding, with intent to kill. The Jury found that he did not intend to kill, and there the intention was of the essence of the crime; that is not so on the present occasion; it is not necessary here to prove any intention to kill; it is only necessary to prove an intention to inflict an injury that might be dangerous to life, and that it resulted in death; that is quite sufficient to sustain the present charge. Try this by the very test which Mr. M'Mahon has presented to us; he says that it is no bar to the second indictment that a

party has been acquitted on the first, unless the facts proved on the second indictment might have produced a conviction on the first; why, a party may be convicted upon an indictment for murder, by evidence that would have no tendency to prove that there was any intent to kill; nay, by evidence that might clearly show he meant to stop short of death, and even took some means to prevent death; but if that illegal act of his produces death, that is murder. Two authorities have been cited with reference to an acquittal or a conviction in a Police Court; one of them was a case before Mr. Justice Coltman, which turned entirely upon a particular Statute (9 Geo. 4, c. 91, sec. 28); and as to the case in 5 Law Chronicle, it is evident that proceeded upon some Act applicable to Scotland; or, if it did not, I entirely dissent from the doctrine there laid down. The only suggestion that raised, for a moment, a doubt in my mind was from Mr. M'Mahon, to the effect that as acquittal of an assault with intent to kill, was an acquittal both of the assault and of the intent; but I think that is not so; the acquittal of the whole offence is not an acquittal of every part of it, it is only an acquittal of the whole; therefore the result of such an acquittal would only be, that the acts were not done with intent to kill; and although it was urged that, under a recent Act of Parliament, it was competent to the Jury to convict of unlawfully wounding, I am not sure, if the whole record had been before us, that that would have presented any sort of answer; but the record is not before us; all we have is, that the Jury acquitted the party of the wounding with intent to kill; that is the only thing we have to deal with. It appears to me, therefore, with reference to all the authorities that have been laid before us, that the two offences are not the same, that the plea cannot be supported, and that the prisoner must answer over. I am authorised to state that Mr. Justice Crompton and Mr. Baron Watson, before whom the case came at the last Session, have looked into the matter, and concur in the view now taken."

MR. BARON MARTIN . was of the same opinion. After alluding to the peculiar form of the plea, which omitted to aver the identity of the crime now charged, with that of which the prisoner had been acquitted, and which omission, in his opinion, was fatal to the plea, he referred to that portion of the argument founded upon the maxim in Hale and other authors, that no man could be tried twice for one and the same crime; that maxim presented a true criterion by which to test this question; was the crime here one and the same? now the offence for which the prisoner had been tried was one of intent, and was therefore complete the moment the stab was given; whereas, the offence for which he was now indicted, could only be consummated by the death of the party. To the mind of any lawyer, this must be deemed conclusive as against the plea, which, on the grounds already referred to, was not to be supported.

MR. JUSTICE WILLES. gave judgment to the same effect. In order to support this plea, it must be shown that the former acquittal was an acquittal of all that state of facts which might constitute the party a murderer. Now, on comparing the two indictments, it was clear that the Jury had not so acquitted him; all that was then disposed of was, that he did not wound with intent to kill; it could not be assumed that they negatived the wounding; therefore, if the wounding, coupled with circumstances not showing an intention to kill, might constitude murder, the prisoner ought now to be tried for that offence; and that this might be the case, was clearly shown by the fact, that persons inflicting wounds whilst engaged in the commission of burglary or robbery, without any intention to kill, would be guilty of murder where death ensued. The learned Judge, after noticing the various points of the argument, concluded by observing that as, in

p.hi: his opinion, the same matter was not again in discussion, the demurrer must be allowed, and judgment given for the Crown.
A Jury, composed half of foreigners, was then sworn, and the prisoner was given in charge, both upon the indictment and Inquisition, for the wilful murder of Robert Henderson Robertson.

div1.p:
RICHARD THOMPSON . I am an attorney at law. In 1856, I was acting as attorney for the prisoner—he had not consulted me in July last—I spoke to him—I was written to by Mr. Robertson to see him—I did see him on some business—on 8th July last, I went to the Queen's Prison, with the prisoner and Mr. Gower—I had spoken to De Salvi as to an arrangement being made for the discharge of Mr. Robertson, who was at that time a prisoner in the Queen's Prison—De Salvi was one of his detaining creditors, Mr. Gower was another, and there were others—it must have been about 2 o'clock when we went to the prison—we went to Mr. Robertson's room—he was not there at the time, he came in afterwards—there was Mr. Robert
son, the prisoner, Mr. Gower, and myself in the room—a conversation took place between the different parties—Mr. Robertson took his seat near the window, I was on his left hand side, the prisoner was standing about four or five, or six feet in front of Mr. Robertson, and Mr. Gower was standing a little further off—I spoke to Mr. Robertson as to his making some proposal to the prisoner and Mr. Gower for his discharge—Mr. Robertson, addressing himself to Mr. Gower, made an explanation as to a debt of 200l. to De Salvi, he said, "The 200l. is owing by a Mr. Brown, it is not my debt"—on that the prisoner said, "I let you have my money, you owe me the money"—Robertson said, "No, Brown had it"—he denied it, and then there was an angry feeling between the prisoner—he seemed vexed at his denying that he had received his 200l.—the angry feeling was expressed by the prisoner—he said, "You had my money"—I cannot recollect exactly the words used by him, but I saw that he was angry with him for denying owing him the 200l.—he repeated the denial more than once—after he had so repeated it, De Salvi got nearer to him, and I saw him strike Robertson with his right hand, placing his left hand on his shoulder, and striking with the right—Robertson was sitting in his chair at the time—he struck him on the right side, in the neck—I should think there were four or five blows given—I could not see anything in the prisoner's hand.—after the blows were struck, Mr. Robertson got forward about four feet, and went to the ground—I immediately jumped up from my seat—De Salvi left the room, and I saw that Robertson was bleeding from a cut in the temple, and I im
mediately took hold of him, and supported him on the ground—De Salvi left the room immediately after the blows were struck, and Mr. Gower also—I called for assistance—some one came into the room, and I said, "Stop those men"—the deceased was afterwards placed on a bed, and attended by a surgeon.

Cross-examined by MR. EDWIN JAMES., Q. C. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. Early in 1856 I brought several actions for him—I under
stand he has been a courier—he was introduced to me as a client—I understood to had saved from 900l. to 1000l. in service—I cannot tell what Robert
son's occupation was—he had an office in Old Broad Street—I do not know that he carried on any business; "Mr. Robertson's office" was on the door—I understood that De Salvi had entrusted to, or lent him, 500l.—Mr. Ashley brought an action against him for 200l. odd, and I brought an action against him for 200l.—I understood that that was money advanced to him out of his savings—on 2nd July, Mr. Robertson addressed a letter to me,
