requesting to see me professionally at the Queen's Prison, and I saw him on 3rd July; and he asked me to speak De Salvi about making some arrange
ment for him—he went with me to the prison on the 8th, in consequence of my sending to him—I saw him prior to the 8th July, and told him if he and Gower would take a sum of money from Robertson, I though I might get the matter arranged—I made an appointment with De Salvi, to accom
pany me to the Queen's Prison, on the 8th, with Gower, for the purpose of making some arrangement—during the conversation in the prison, it transpired that Robertson had been under some Scotch sequestration or bankruptcy—he was detained in the Queen's Bench for 200l., part of the money De Salvi had advanced to him—he denied having had the 200l., and said it was Brown's debt, not his—it was upon that that the angry feeling arose—both the parties became excited; that is, Mr. Grower and Mr. Robertson were much excited, and on Mr. Robertson addressing Mr. Gower, as "My dear sir," he said to him, "Don't call me my dear sir, call me Mr. Gower;" and he told him he had opposed him in Scotland, and he should oppose him here—he accused Robertson of fraud—Mr. Gower is the gentleman who keeps the repository in Barbican—it was on Robertson stating to De Salvi that he had not had his money that De Salvi became excited—De Salvi made use of a good many words to him, but I cannot recollect them—he charged Robertson with falsehood in stating that he had not had his money—the blows followed very shortly upon that—it wets within a very short space of time—the angry feeling continued until the blows were struck—there was no preparation, or I should have seen it.

MR. BODKIN. Q. If I understand you, the angry feeling was principally between Mr. Gower and Mr. Robertson? A. It was by both of them; Mr. Gower first stated that he had opposed him in Scotland, and he should oppose him at his meeting in the Queen's Bench, and when he went up to the Insolvent Debtors' Court—I think Robertson's words to De Salvi were "It is no debt of mine, it is Mr. Brown's," and, "Mr. Brown had your money."

CHARLES EDWARD WILDE . On 8th July last, I was a prisoner in the Queen's Bench Prison. About 2 o'clock that day, I observed the prisoner, Mr. Gower, and Mr. Thompson, go up stairs towards Mr. Robertson's room—about five or six minutes after they had gone in, I heard a scuffle, and I saw the prisoner run out of the room, and Mr. Gower after him—they ran along the corridor towards the stairs—I went immediately to Mr. Robert son's room and found him wounded and bleeding, supported by Mr. Thomp
son—I then followed the direction that the prisoner and Gower had taken, but did not come up with them—I returned towards Mr. Robertson's room—before I got there, I saw this knife lying down on the ground between Mr. Robertson's room and the stairs to which the prisoner and Gower had run; it is in the same state as it was then, except that there were some marks of blood upon it—I then went down stairs and found the prisoner and Mr. Gower detained—I said to the prisoner, "You are the assassin; your name is Salvi"—he made no answer, but started back in voluntarily.

JOHN WILCOX WAKEM . I am a surgeon, and attend at the Queen's Bench Prison. On the afternoon of 8th July, I was called to see Mr. Robertson, he was in his room—I found him wounded; he had one wound on the right temple, one by the side of the face, one on the right side, another over the collar bone on the right side, and one at the nape of the neck, five in all—I attended him from that day until the 22nd Aug., when he died in the prison—at that time the whole of the wounds had healed

externally—after death I made an examination—I found a portion of knife adhering to one of the vertebrae—it had transfixed the spinns process of the vertebrae and completely passed through it, the point emerging at about the anterior portion of the neck, to the extent of about a quarter of an inch—the division of the spinal marrow was the cause of death—about three-fourths of it was divided, he was entirely paralyzed on one side and partly on the other—I have here the portion of the spinal cord with the portion of knife in the position in which I found it (producing it)—it must have required very great force, indeed, to inflict that blow; the portion of bone cut through is extremely hard—I have compared the knife produced with this portion in the spine; it appears to be a portion of it.

CHARLES COLWELL . I am chief turnkey at the Queen's Bench Prison. I was on duty there, on July last, when this occurred—I took the prisoner into custody—I also detained Mr. Gower, who was with him—I placed De Salvi in a room separated by a glass door from the room in which Mr. Gower was placed—De Salvi wished to speak to Gower, and Gower refused to have any conversation with him—De Salvi on that said, "I did it; no other person had anything to do with it."

p.hi: The Rt. Hon. Earl Granville; Rev. E. Goddard, Vicar of Eartham, Sussex; Richard Buckner, Esq., artist; James Lockhart, Esq., gentleman; Thomas Thomas, Hatchard's Hotel, Piccadilly; and the Rev. Dr. Manning, deposed to the prisoner's good character.
Fifteen Years Penal Servitude, to be concurrent with his former sentence, only commencing from the present conviction.

div1.p:
1126.
HENRY FOLEY HALL ,
Feloniously forging and uttering 3 forged orders for the payment of 5l., 2l. 12s., and 3l., with intent to defraud: to all which he
PLEADED GUILTY .
(The prisoner received a good character.)

1127.
MARY ANN JONES (28),
Feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged 5l. Bank of England note.
MESSRS. GIFFARD. and BAYLEY. conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS GRAY . I am a steam engine smith, in the employment of Messrs. Moseley, of Westminster Road. On 28th July last, I was at the corner of the Tower public house, at the corner of Tower Street, Westminster Road, and saw the prisoner—I had some conversation with her—I did not know her before—two of my children were there during the time—she said she had been a governess, but was out of a situation, and that she could teach my children in the way they ought to be brought up—she asked me if they could say their prayers and their hymns, if not, she could teach them—after a little time she called me out of the house, and asked me if I was known there, and said she was not in her own neighbourhood, and she was short of cash, would I be so kind as to get her a 5l. note changed—she pro
duced a roll of paper out of her pocket, and inside those, fifteen or sixteen pieces of paper—it was rolled up, and at last the 5l. note was produced, and I aid, "Is it a good one?"—she said, "Yes; or I would not ask you to change it"—I took it into Mr. Salisbury, the landlord, and he changed it for me, and I gave the change to the prisoner—I wrote my name on the back of the note; that (produced) is my name—we sat there, and had something to drink for some considerable time afterwards, when it was proposed for us
to go to the Victoria Theatre—I had to go by my house to go there and we went there to have some tea.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. At what time in the day did you first meet with the prisoner? A. It might be between 2 and 3 o'clock in the afternoon—other persons were with me—I continued drinking with her for some time prior to this happening—we were drinking with one another, and we treated one another—it might be two or three hours after the note had been changed that she left—I dare say it was as much as between three and four hours—my attention was first called to this matter after 28th July, on the 3rd or 5th Aug., I will not be sure which—I continued in her company up till nearly 12 o'clock at night—I did not find out what her calling was—I did not discover that she was what is called an unfortunate girl—I swear that—after the theatre, we went to a public house, and had some gin, and I never saw her afterwards till I saw her at the station house a fortnight ago—I am a widower with four children—two of my children were with me all the time—one is nine and the other in seven.

EDWARD SALISBURY . I keep the Tower public house, in Westminster Road. I remember changing a note for the last witness on 28th July last—I wrote my name on it two days afterwards when I paid it away—this is the note—Gray wrote his name on it.

Cross-examined. Q. You saw the prisoner there, did you, on the same occasion that Gray was there, and had the note changed? A. Yes; she was sitting in the bar in company with Gray, and two or three of his fellow workmen.

EDWARD NEWTON . (Policeman, L 76). I took the prisoner into custody on 12th Oct., in Webber Street. I told her that I wanted her for passing a forged 5l. note, at the Tower public house—she said, "If I did, I did not know it was a bad one, as I had it from a gentleman"—she lives in Granby Street, Waterloo Road—that is about one of the worst streets in London, a regular den of brothels and thieves—a woman who was not a prostitute would not be likely to be seen there—there are but two decent women there.

Cross-examined. Q. You had known her as an unfortunate girl, had you not? A. Yes; some time—there are two or three respectable persons in Granby Street; there is the public house, and the greengrocer's shop.
NOT GUILTY .

1128.
SUSAN HUMBY (26),
Feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged 10l. Bank of England note.
MESSRS. GIFFARD. and BAYLEY. conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE THOMAS TOBY . I am a shoemaker, and live at No. 41, Wel
lington Street, London Bridge. On Monday, the 12th of this month, the prisoner called at my shop about 10 o'clock in the morning—she brought a written order for boots and shoes, and said she wished the goods sent to the Wandsworth Road—I asked her what name, and she gave me the name of Stevens, Cavendish Terrace, Wandsworth Road—No. 7, I think it was—I wrote that on the order—the order is not here; it was mislaid and lost—it was a ready money transaction, or supposed to be so, and of course was not filed—she said if the goods were sent that evening, the money should be returned, that they were to be sent by 6 o'clock, because they were going to open a new shop—the goods were sent that evening—the man came back, and brought back a 10l. note with the name of Stevens, Cavendish Terrace, written on it—this (produced) is the note—I thought it was a bad one, and I put my initials on it—I paid it into the bankers the

following morning the first thing—they sent it back about 11 or half past 11 o'clock that morning—I and Lock went to No. 7, Cavendish Terrace, the same morning—I found the house empty, and the people gone—I went into the house—I did not find my goods there—I afterwards went to Mr. Finch, No. 5, Gray's Buildings, Lambeth, about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and saw the prisoner there—I gave her into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. You found that her father lived at No. 5, Gray's Buildings, did not you? A. I did not know it was her father—I know it since then—it is in George Street, Lambeth—I told her that I wanted to see Stevens, and she then answered me that she thought Stevens would be there about half past 5 o'clock—I went at half past 5 o'clock, and there was no one in the house at all, and I went at 7 o'clock and found the prisoner there, and gave her into custody—there was no one there then—I told her she was given into custody for uttering a forged 10l. note—she said she was not aware it was a bad one—she did not say she could not read or write.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. What did she say about Stevens? A. She said she expected him there about half past 5 o'clock in the morning—she said they were going to open a new shop in Cavendish Terrace, and thought it would do very well because it was near the station.

JOHN LOCK . I am Mr. Toby's shopman. On 12th of this month I went to Cavendish Terrace with some boots and shoes—a man opened the door—the prisoner was within hearing—the man asked me what I wanted—I told him I had brought some boots and shoes—he said to the prisoner, "Here is the man with the boots and shoes"—she said, "Tell the man to walk in"—I went in, put the boots and shoes on the floor, and gave her the invoice of them—she opened the invoice—the bill was 10l. 7s. 3d.—she said that they were out—she did not mention the names, and there was only a 10l. note left, thinking what little there was over would be discount—I told her it was nett cash, no discount could be taken off, and she called in the man who was standing outside the door, and as they had no change to pay me the difference, it was agreed on that they were to call and pay the balance the first time they were passing—the prisoner spoke—I then counted out the goods on the counter, and was paid with a 10l. note by the prisoner—I did not observe where she took it from—the man was standing by the side of her, and I wished him to put his name at the back of it, and he put the name of "G. Stevens, Cavendish Terrace"—I gave that same note to my master.

Cross-examined. Q. The man was present, was he not, when the invoice was opened? A. No; he opened the door and asked me what I wanted, and I told him I had brought the boots and shoes—I put them down on the floor directly I got in the shop—the man and woman did not count them; I did myself—I did not see where the note came from—the woman gave it to me—I did not see the man give it to the woman—it was not given to the woman in my presence—the man put his name on the back of it.

JOHN WHITE . (Policeman, L 39). On Tuesday, 13th of this month, I went to No. 5, Gray's Place, Lambeth—the prisoner was given into my custody—on the road to the station, she told me that a gentleman of the name of Miller gave her husband the note, but she did not know where he lived.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not she also say, when you took her, that the man with whom she lived had put his name on the note? A. Yes; her husband, she said, and she paid it away—I did not know her before, nor her father.

JOHN LASH . I am shopman to Mr. Brier, 44, King William Street, City. On Friday, 9th Oct., the prisoner came into Mr. Brier's shop, and brought a written order for some haberdashery and hosiery—I was scarcely able to read it, and I asked her by word of mouth for her address—she gave, "Mrs. Humby, Cavendish Grove, Cavendish Square, Wandsworth Road, the corner shop"—I told her that the goods would be sent on—they came to 5l. 7s. 3d.

Cross-examined. Q. How was the order written? A. In pencil—I had not seen her before I served her—she was in the shop above an hour—she knew nothing about the goods she was purchasing; she left it to me.

JAMES JOSEPH COLTMAN . I am a warehouseman in the same employ as the last witness, and have the management of the parcels department—I sent a parcel by a porter, named William Brown, to Mrs. Humby—it was sent three times to that address; on the 9th, 10th, and 12th—on the third time, the 12th, he brought back a 5l. note in payment of the goods—I wrote, "Mrs. Humby, Cavendish Terrace, Wandsworth Road, 12, 10, 7." upon it—this (produced) is it.

WILLIAM BROWN . I am a porter in Mr. Brier's employment I took a parcel of goods on the morning of the 12th of this month—I took it once before, on the 10th, but I did not deliver it because I found no one there; the shop was closed—I took it on the 12th to Cavendish Grove, at the corner of Cavendish Terrace, Wandsworth Road—I looked in at the doorway; there were two shutters down—I saw the prisoner in there—I knocked at the door, and she came and opened it—I told her I had brought the parcel from Mr. Brier, of London Bridge, for Mrs. Humby—she said, "Come in, it is all right"—I took the bill for the goods out of my pocket, opened it, and gave it to her, and told her the amount of it, 5l. 7s. 3½d.—she opened a till underneath the counter, and took out two notes, one a 5l. and the other a 10l.—she gave me the 5l. note—I asked her whether she had not got any silver to pay the remainder—she said she had not any more money besides those two notes; the gentleman had not left her any money, but she expected him in a minute or two—I waited there half an hour or more, but found no gentleman ever came—I told her I must go; she said I must take some of the goods back to make the money balance—I looked in the parcel, and saw a dozen hose at 6s. 9d., and I took them back—the balance over was 7s. 3½d.—I selected something as near as I could to it—there was 6½d. more to come to me—I then left the shop, and brought the 6s. 9d. parcel along with me and the note, which I gave to Coltman when I got back.
Cross-examined. Q. She made no objection to your waiting? A. No; she said the gentleman would be in a few minutes.

JAMES HENRY TURNER . I keep the Globe public house, Regent Street. Lambeth. On the 8th of this month the prisoner came to my house, and asked me to oblige her with change for a 5l. note—she placed one on the counter I looked at it, and I said it was a funny looking note, and I did not like to change notes for strangers—she said, "You know me very well; we have dealt here for years; it is for my father; you may rely upon its being good for he took it at Somerset House"—I never knew what her father was; I have Known him by sight for years; I asked her name, and she said, "Finch, No. 5, Gray's Place"—I asked her to write her name and address on it; she said she could not write, would I write it for her; and I wrote, "Finch, No. 5, Gray's Place"—that is the note—I gave her four sovereigns and 1l. in silver, change.

Cross-examined. Q. You did know her father by sight? A. Yes—I have known him about the neighbourhood—I have not been in business long—I have not seen a great many Bank of England notes—it was differ
ent from the one I had—I compared the two—I do not know whether her father is in Court here—(he was here brought forward)—that is the man I mean—I afterwards saw the father—he did not say he had sent it—he said, "It is a bad job, I will make it good to you."
JOSEPH BUMSTEAD . They are all forged—the two fives are from the same plate.

JOSEPH FINCH . (examined by MR. LILLEY.). I live at No. 5, Gray's Place. I am the prisoner's father—she was formerly married to a man named Humby, who committed suicide, and that had so great an effect upon her that she was an inmate of a lunatic asylum for, I should think, about three months; and since that time she has been rather simple minded—I know a man named Stevens, and I knew that he was paying his addresses, intend
ing to be married to my daughter, and the banns were published—after this bad job about the note, inquiries were made after Stevens, and he was not to be found—I do not know a young woman named Jordan—I know her mother—the young woman was missing at the same time as Stevens was missing—I had so much confidence in Stevens under existing circumstance, that I gave him a reference; I mean from his being about to marry my daughter—I did not know anything to his disadvantage at that time—I am in no occupation; I have a trifle to live on—my daughter can read and write very imperfectly.
NOT GUILTY .

1129.
HENRY WELCH (37),
Feloniously killing and slaying
Eliza Welch; he was charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the like offence.
MR. ROBINSON. conducted the Prosecution.

ANDREW MOORE . I am a stoker employed at the London Gas Factory, It Vauxhall. I had been for some time, previously to Saturday, 19th Sept., living with Welch and his wife as a lodger, at No. 4, Newmarket Buildings, Vauxhall—on the night of Sept 19th, I went with the prisoner to Brixton to see his daughter—I returned with him about half past 9 o'clock—we had left the house to go there about a quarter to 6 o'clock in the evening—the wife was then at home—nothing took place at that time between the hus
band and the wife—when we returned home at half past 9 o'clock, she was not there—the prisoner went into the factory, I went to bed; that was at half past 9 o'clock—the factory is not above twenty yards from where he lived, right opposite—I saw him again at the house, about half past 12 o'clock—I got up because I heard them quarrelling—I cannot tell when she came home—I did not go to sleep at once—I suppose it was somewhere about an hour before the came home—I can say that she did not come home for an hour after half past 9 o'clock—when I heard them quarrelling I got up and dressed, and went into their room—I heard the husband ask the wife where she had been to, and she told him that she went in search of him and the little boy—he said she knew very well where he was gone to—he told me he had found her outside a beer shop, in Vauxhall Walk; he had just come home—she appeared to be a little gone in liquor—he appeared to me per
fectly sober—I heard her keep on telling her husband that she had been in search of him, and he said she had not, she was out drinking with other people—she said she was not—at the time this altercation took place, she was sitting on a chair close against the door going into the bedroom—he

was sitting on the opposite side close to the window—there was a table be
tween them—he then got up and struck her a blow, which caused her to fall—it was a round handed blow with his open hand—she fell against the door post—I do not recollect what was said by either of them immediately before that blow was struck—he had attempted to strike her once before, and I interfered and stopped him—that was five or ten minutes before he got up and went towards her—I interfered and prevented him, and he sat down again—when she fell against the door post, I went to pick her up—she appeared to be helpless—she was sensible, but it appeared to me that she could not stand—I do not think she could have got up without assist
ance—I put her on the chair—I noticed a slight bruise on the side of the cheek, by the eye—I cannot say which part of her head struck the door—her head did strike it—her husband ordered her to bed, and she went into the bed room—she could walk then—that was about ten minutes after I put her on the chair—the prisoner was sitting on a chair during that time—he was not doing anything—I went outside for about three minutes, and when I came in again I opened the room door where he was standing, went into my bedroom, and went to bed—I did not hear any noise from her when he struck her—she only hallooed, "Oh, Harry!"—I heard nothing of them in the night—I saw the prisoner next morning, about 20 minutes past 5 o'clock—he came out of his bedroom and called me—he generally gives me a call in the morning to go to work—this was Sunday morning—I work on Sunday—that was the usual time he called me—I asked him how his wife was—he said she was in the room asleep—I asked him if she was ill—he said, "No"—I looked into the room, and saw her lying down—there did not appear to be anything the matter with her.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Where was your room; was it over the room in which the prisoner and his wife lived? A. No; on the same floor—my door was not opposite the prisoner's; it was on the same floor—I could easily hear what passed in the prisoner's room, if the door was not fastened—I could not hear a word without speaking very loud—amongst other things, I heard the prisoner complain of the children being left, neglected and crying—the children were about four or five months old—he asked her what money she had in her possession—she told him, I think, 12s. or 13s.—I am sure she said as much as that—she did not show it—I have known the prisoner from a child—I have known him and his wife living together about twelve years—as long as I have known him, his conduct towards her has been kind and affectionate—the only blow I saw was a slap on the side of the face.

ELIZA HUDSON . I am the wife of Bryan Jessie Hudson, a hatter. I live in High Street, Vauxhall, next door to Welch, the prisoner. On 20th Sept., about half past 10 o'clock in the morning, I was sent for by Welch—I went in, and saw Mr. and Mrs. Welch—she was in bed, and he was applying leeches to her temples—she appeared insensible—her face was much swollen on the left side, and discoloured—she was rather restless, and moved herself about, but I do not think she was conscious—I did not remain—I left imme
diately, without saying anything—at my husband's desire, I went in again in the evening, in consequence of what I heard—she was still in bed, and he was sitting down by her side—I then applied a blister to the back of her neck—he requested me to do so—she was still insensible, but rather restless—the prisoner said, "Mrs. Hudson, this is a bad job; she went out drink
ing, and I was very much exasperated, and when she returned home, I gave her an open handed blow, and she fell; and that was the cause of this"—I

saw her again on the Monday—he was still attending on her—he was most attentive—she rallied a little on the 27th, and sat up in bed, and opened one of her eyes—she was attended by Mr. Thompson—she said to me, in the pri
soner's presence, "Mrs. Hudson, you are here"—I said, "Yes"—she said, "I feel very curious; I feel beery; I have been sadly used, but by whom I do not know"—the prisoner was standing at the right side of her, and he replied, "By me, my dear"—nothing more was said then—she relapsed into a sort of stupor—on 26th she was well enough to get up and dress herself; and she ate four eggs, a quarter of a pound of bacon, and drank seven cups of tea—she relapsed again on Monday, and died on 2nd Oct., at 12 o'clock at night—I saw her on 24th and 25th Sept.—on the 25th she was in a saner state of mind than she was on the 24th—she said to her husband, "Harry, come here and lie down by my bedside; what money did I bring you home on Satur
day night?"—he replied, "12s. and some odd halfpence"—she said, "My God! if you will say that, you will drive me mad"—he said, "Can you recollect where you went to on Saturday evening?"—she said "Yes; I went round the Potteries to look for the boy; I went round to the Distiller's Arms, and drank out of two or three pots of beer; and from there I went down Lambeth Walk, and called at the shoemaker's, and went over to the Feathers, and we had two half pints of gin; one I paid for, and the other was paid for; there were five in company; I returned from there up to the Jolly Gardeners, and had a small portion of rum; I returned from there to the John Bull, and insulted a man of the name of Hasley; I had a small portion of rum there; I then went again to the Distiller's Arms, and had a small drop of beer, and at ten minutes to 12 o'clock I looked in at Ward's to see if my husband was there; I then went home to get a saucer to get something in, and in Vauxhall Walk I had a glass of ale, and that is where Welch found me"—he said the cause of his beating her was, that he was so exasperated at her leaving the children crying so many hours.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you known her some little time before? A. A year and a quarter—I should say his conduct was generally that of a kind and affectionate husband to her—they have two babies—there are five chil
dren—two have died—they are all young—the eldest is nearly fourteen, another eleven, and the others very small.
COURT. Q. Did she say what passed when she insulted the man? A. No, she did not—she could not recollect that properly.

HONOR STAFFORD . I am a widow, and live at No. 4, Model Buildings, Vauxhall, in the same house and on the same floor as the prisoner and his wife; our doors are just facing one another. On Sunday night, 20th Sept., between 12 and 1 o'clock, I heard Mrs. Welch screaming, and saying, "You will kill me"—I jumped out of bed, and went to the door in my night dress—I saw Welch just within his own door, making, as I thought, towards the landing—I returned into my own apartment, locked the door, and went to bed—I heard no more—I did not see Mrs. Welch—I heard no screams after that.

Cross-examined. Q. It lasted a very short time? A. A very short time, what I noticed of it—I have known the prisoner about twelve months—I believe his conduct was affectionate to his wife—I am no acquaintance of theirs.

WILLIAM ERTHWAITE THOMPSON . I am a surgeon, in Vauxhall Walk. On Sunday morning, 20th Sept., I was called by the prisoner about 9 o'clock—I went with him to his lodgings, and found his wife lying in bed in a state of partial insensibility—I aroused her a little—she complained of pain in her

head—I examined it, and discovered a contusion over the left eye, and one on the eye to some considerable extent, over the orbit, near the eyebrow—it was a black eye—there was also a superficial bruise on the left ear—there was no abrasion of the skin, or wound of any sort—she was not perfectly insensible—she could answer, but very incoherently—I consider the wounds I saw to be the result of violence; but in what way produced, of course, I could not say—I should say one blow would be sufficient to produce what I saw—a blow with the open hand, given to a person in a state of intoxication, and a fall of considerable force against a hard body, would be sufficient to account for it—I attended her continually, and had hopes of her ultimate recovery, but she subsequently relapsed, and died delirious; I may almost say maniacal—I opened the head after death—on removing the skull. I found a quantity of extravasated blood which had escaped from a ruptured vessel beneath the left lobe of the brain—that blood had coagulated and caused the pressure, paralysis, and death—in my judgment, that was caused by violence—the clot of blood under the brain was just above the orifice of the eye—I think such a blow and fall as she is described to have received. would be sufficient to produce death—I found the liver considerably harder than natural, and its structure was diseased—I should say that the deceased was evidently a woman of intemperate habits.

Cross-examined. Q. You were fetched by the prisoner himself? A. I was—he appeared to be very anxious about his wife, and evinced the kindest manner and most attentive conduct—a fall would have produced the injuries I saw—I should infer that the rupture was very slight—I have seen drink
ing produce paralysis; but then it alters very materially the structure of the brain; and this was not so altered.

ISAAC SHEPHERD . (Policeman, L 49). I took the prisoner into custody on 28th Sept. for violently assaulting his wife, who was then lying in a dan
gerous state—I said, "Do you deny it or not?"—he said, "No; I acknow
ledge giving her a pat on the head with my open hand, and she fell down."
ANDREW MOORE . re-examined. The deceased had no injury done to her eye when I first saw her—I think I should have seen it if she had.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

1130.
SARAH SMITH (23), was indicted
for unlawfully uttering coun
terfeit coin.
MESSRS. CLERK. and W. J. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

MYRA THORNE . I am servant to Mr. Putley, a butcher, of High Street, Borough. On 2nd Sept the prisoner came about 9 o'clock in the morning for a pound of steak; I did not serve her, but she paid me with a half crown, which I looked at, and gave to Mr. Putley, who sounded it, and gave it back to me; I put it into the bowl with some more silver and one half crown at the bottom—I put this half crown on the top of the silver—I gave her change before I put the half crown in the bowl; she left; and directly she had gone, I took the half crown out of the bowl and gave it to Mr. Putley.

Prisoner. Q. Did not he say that it was good? A. He sounded it, and said, "That will do"—I did not put it into the bowl before I gave you the change—I have seen you once or twice before dealing at the shop.

GEORGE PUTLEY . I am a butcher, of High Street, Borough. I was at home when the prisoner came—I sounded the half crown, and said, "Well, that will do"—it was rather dark—I saw the prisoner receive change from the last witness, who put the half crown in the bowl, I should say after the change was given; it is not our practice to put it in first—immediately

she was gone my attention was attracted to it, and I went after the pri
soner; I found her five or six doors off, showed her the half crown, and told her it was bad—she said that it was not the same—I gave her in Cus
tody—I found another half crown in the bowl, but it was underneath 30s. worth of silver, and was of a different make.

LOT SAWYER . (Policeman, M 175). I took the prisoner, took her back to the shop, and received a half crown from Mr. Putley—the 1s. 4d. change was found on the prisoner by the female searcher, who is not here.

MARY HUNTINGTON . My father is a potato salesman, in the Borough. The prisoner came there on Saturday night, 29th Aug., a few minutes before 12 o'clock, for six pounds of potatoes, which came to 6d.; she gave me a counterfeit shilling—I said, "Are you aware that this is bad?"—she said "No"—I said, "How many more have you?"—she said, "Very likely fifty"—I bent it in a detector, and put it in the farthing compartment of the till; and kept it there till I gave it to Baldry.

Prisoner. I deny all knowledge of it. Witness. I am certain she is the person—I have never seen her before—there was no one else in the shop—there was a gas light—I called a policeman in, and asked him if he knew her—he said that he did not—I showed him the shilling, but did not wish to be severe, and let her go.

JOSEPH BALDRY . (Policeman, M 71). On 29th Aug., I was called by Miss Huntington, and saw the prisoner in the shop; she said that she was not aware the shilling was bad, and she was allowed to go; I received this shil
ling from Miss Huntington on 2nd Sept.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. This half crown and shilling are both bad.
Prisoner's Defence. There was another in the till, and I am positive the gentleman who gave me that would not give me a bad one.
NOT GUILTY .

1131.
JOHN WELCH (35) and
JOSEPH SEERS (29), were indicted for
a like offence.
MESSRS. CLERK. and W. J. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

LYDIA EDWARDS . I am barmaid at the Coach and Horses, at Kew. On Friday, 22nd Sept., between 7 and 8 o'clock in the morning, Seers came for a half pint of gin; it came to 8d.; he gave me a sovereign, which I put into a little box in the bureau drawer, where there was no other money—I gave him change, and he took the gin away in a bottle—Moore was present; about 8 o'clock, or a little after, he came again for a pint of 6d. ale, and gave me a good sixpence—he was in the habit of using the house; on the day before I had seen him with Welch, they went into the tap room toge
ther—they used the house to breakfast, and sometimes they came in the after
noon too—on the morning of the 22nd, between 9 and 10 o'clock, Mrs. Huntley came to me with a sovereign in her hand, and in consequence of what she said, I went to a building of Mr. Ridley, a little further up the road, to try to find Seers, but he was not there—in the afternoon I saw him on an omnibus; I am quite sure he paid for that gin with a sovereign, and not with a half crown.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Do you supply breakfast for the working men about there? A. We make tea for three or four sometimes, and some
times not for one; I may have seen Seers with other men besides Welch.

MR. CLERK. Q. Have you seen both these men at your house to breakfast? A. Yes, not on more than one occasion; but I have seen them together frequently, and two or three others sometimes—I have seen them together and no others, once or twice—when Seers put down the
sovereign, he said, "I have not got change, you must find change or I cannot pay you for the gin"—I looked for change and found it.

MARY MOORE . I am cook at the Coach and Horses. I saw Seers served with half a pint of gin, on 22nd Sept.—he paid with a sovereign—the bar
maid hesitated and said, "I do not know that I can give you change"—he said, "You must find change, or how am I to pay you for the gin?"—I saw change given out of a piece of newspaper—the principal part of it was in half crowns.
Seers. Q. Where were you? A. Close by the parlour door—I was not coming up out of the kitchen.

JANE HUNTLEY . I am the wife of Reuben Huntley, who keeps the Coach and Horses, at Kew. On 22nd Sept., between 9 and 10 o'clock, a boy brought what appeared to be a sovereign, from Warden and Fletcher, the butchers, nearly opposite, for change—I did not lift it off the counter, but said that it was bad, and the boy took it back—about a quarter of an hour afterwards I went to a drawer in my bureau, and found a counterfeit sovereign—in consequence of what my niece, Miss Edwards, said, I gave my husband the sovereign I found in the box, and went with him to Mr. Ripley's building to look for Seers, whom I knew by sight—I afterwards saw him on an omnibus in the afternoon—my husband was with him, and my niece was called out to identify him—I have seen Welch at the house, generally with others—the prisoners have had breakfast at our house, I cannot say when.

REUBEN JAMES HUNTLEY . I am the landlord of the Coach and Horses. I went with my barmaid to Ridley's building after Seers, but did not find him, and then went to the Waggon and Horses, at Kew, which is just across the, bridge, and saw Hawkins, the ostler—in consequence of what I said to him, he got on horseback, and went towards London—I was at Kew between 2 and 3 o'clock, and Seers was brought there on an omnibus by an officer—I called my niece out, and she recognised him—I then got on the omnibus, and went to the police station, at Richmond—I recognised Seers as man to whom I had given a pint of beer the day before, without paying for it, for taking care of some things—I said, "You are the man to whom I gave a pint of beer yesterday"—he said, "I am"—I said, "You gave me a bad sovereign; you did not ought to have served me in that way"—he made no answer for some time, and then said that it was not a sovereign he gave, it was half a crown—I asked him how he came to leave his work—he said, "A man will do anything when he is tight, or three sheets"—he had been drinking—my wife gave me this counterfeit sovereign—I marked it with a penknife, with a cross on the head side, and gave it to the officer.

Seers. Q. Did not you ask another man, who was at work on the build
ing, whether he had not been to your house after gin? A. No—I did not ask Welch, but I saw him on the scaffold, turning his back to me.

CHARLES HAWKINS . I am ostler at the Waggon and Horses, Kew Bridge—the prisoners lodged there for eight nights before 22nd Sept.—they occupied a small room to themselves—I remember Mr. Huntley coming over the bridge to me, at a little before 10 o'clock that morning—I had seen Seers about half past nine o'clock—he was then in liquor, and told me that he was going to the hospital to see his father, who was ill—I told Mr. Huntley where I had seen Seers go, and I got on horseback, and overtook him on an omnibus, going towards London—he said, "Halloo, Charley, what are you after?"—I said, "Nothing particular"—I stopped the omnibus, called a policeman, and gave him into custody—I did not then know what the charge was.
Cross-examined. Q. Did the pot boy sleep in the room too? A. Yes, and Welch slept with him.

Seers. Q. Was not there any one who slept with me? A. Yes, a brick
layer's lad—the pot boy did not always sleep in that room.

JOHN GOLDING . I am foreman to Fletcher and Warden, butchers, at Kew—on 22nd Sept, about a quarter to 8 o'clock, Welch came for a mutton chop, and gave me a sovereign; I gave him 19s. 7d. change, and took it in doors to Miss Warden, who acts as cashier—Seers had been to my house that morning for some beef steak, which came to 7d. or 9d., and paid me with a half crown—he did not appear to be drunk—I got change from Miss Warden—he said, "Well, I did not know you would have to go after change, or else I would have let it be till by-and-by "—I did not know what he meant—I have seen Welch at my house several times, purchasing things—Miss Warden afterwards gave me the sovereign, and I marked it, and gave it to the policeman—in the course of that day I went to Ridley's buildings to look for Welch, and found him doing something on the roof, in his shirt sleeves—he was in his jacket when he came to my house—I have no doubt at all that he is the person—Henry Smith was in the shop.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you any doubt now? A. Not much, but I had at the time; so much so, that I left him to look for somebody else—I said that I could not see any person like the man—it was after that that I made up my mind that it must be Welch—the prisoner said something about not taking him into custody if I could not make up my mind—I had a strong suspicion, but there was a difference in his dress—he was not taken for an hour and a half or two hours after that—I have seen him come to my house, but I never saw him with anybody else; he Has come and bought articles several times.

MR. CLERK. Q. You told the prosecutor that you had a strong suspicion that Welch was the man; how near were you to him? A. He was upon a high place and I was on the ground; he continued at his work while I went round the building—he was about eight feet above me, he had no conversa
tion with me, or with the policeman—when he came away from the building with the policeman he had his jacket on, and then I could swear to him.

SUSANNAH WARDEN . I act as cashier to Messrs. Fletcher and Warden. On 22nd Sept. Golding gave me a sovereign about a quarter to 8 o'clock in the morning; I gave him the change, half a sovereign and 9s. 6d. in silver—I put the sovereign into a little bowl which was empty—about two hours afterwards I gave it to Philip Nunn, the shop boy, and sent him to the Coach and Horses for change—he brought it back and I put it in a desk, where it remained till I gave it to the policeman—Golding marked it.
PHILIP NUNN . I am shop boy to Messrs. Fletcher. On 22nd Sept. Miss Warden gave me a sovereign to get changed at Mr. Huntley's; I brought it back and gave it to her.
Cross-examined. Q. Do any of these men work about there? A. I have seen Welch twice.

HENRY SMITH . I am journeyman to Messrs. Fletcher. I remember Welch coming to buy a mutton chop, Golding served him—he gave a piece of money to Golding, who went to get change—I saw him give the change, a half sovereign, 9s. 6d. in silver, and 1d.—I think I had seen Welch in the shop before, but not to take notice of him—I have not the least doubt of his being the man—Seers afterwards came for a bit of mutton, but he bought a bit of beefsteak—I saw Welch again on the building about 10 o'clock.

Cross-examined. Q. You were not certain at first that he was the man? A. No, I said I thought he was the man, but would not say positively—I am positive I did not say that I did not think he was the man—the police-man said, "You cannot say positively that he is the man, and I cannot take him"—I went round the building to see if I could see anybody else—I had a strong suspicion of him, and when he put his jacket on I knew him by his face; it put a different appearance on his features—I saw that he had a cord jacket when he came into the shop, and if it was shown that I was mistaken, I have not the least doubt that I could swear to his face—after the sovereign was found to be bad, Golding sent for me and asked me if I should know the man—I said that I should know him at once if I saw him.

WILLIAM HARKER . I am waiter and potman at the King's Arms, Kew. On Tuesday, 22nd Sept., about 8 o'clock in the morning, Welch came with a lad, who ordered three basins of coffee or tea—Seers came about a quarter of an hour afterwards, and they breakfasted together at one table—Seers had one of the three basins—Welch asked me to cook a mutton chop for him, which he brought with him, and I did so; he pulled his money out, and said that he had got half a sovereign more than he thought he had, besides several half crowns and shillings—I saw the half sovereign—he said that he had been out on the drink, and he should put it in a pocket by itself—I did not see that he was any the worse for liquor—Seers seemed as if he had been drinking over night, but did not seem tipsy then.

Cross-examined. Q. How soon after the 22nd were you spoken to about this matter? A. About 12 o'clock on the same day—a policeman came and asked me if they had been there to breakfast—I had only those three to breakfast that morning.

DANIEL LANGFORD . (Policeman, N 137). On 22nd Sept., about a quarter to 11 o'clock, I received from Mr. Huntley a counterfeit sovereign, marked with a cross on the head—I also received another counterfeit sovereign from John Golding, in Miss Warden's presence—I went with Fletcher to look for Welch; he was on the roof of the building, and I did not take him at first—I afterwards went to the King's Arms and made inquiry—I went round the building, and Welch was then on the ground—I asked him what he had had for breakfast; he said, "Some meat and pudding, the same as the other men"—I asked him where he had had breakfast; he said, "At the King's Arms"—I asked him if he had had a mutton chop for breakfast—he said, "No"—when he was at his dinner I took him into custody—I found Seers at the station at Kensington, and brought him from there on an omnibus—I searched him at the station and found on him 15s. 6d. in silver, and 4d. in copper—I searched Welch and found on him 8s. 6d. in silver, and 8d. in copper—when I saw Welch at the building, he had no jacket or waistcoat on; when I saw him at dinner he had a jacket on, but no waist
coat—I gave him into the custody of another constable.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you say that you took him for passing a coun
terfeit sovereign? A. Yes; he said, "It is not me, you are mistaken"—there were four or five workmen at the building; there may have been one near his height, but nothing like him—the witnesses were not quite certain at first, and I would not take him for an hour or an hour and a half.
COURT. Q. Did you go with Golding and Smith round the building? A. Yes; neither of them picked out any other man—the other men were carpenters and painters, and Welch is a bricklayer's labourer.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These two coins are bad, and from the, same mould—they are covered with gold, and are considerably less than the proper weight—they ought to have been detected at once.

Seers' Defence. It was a half crown that I gave, and I received 1s. 10d. I had been having a drop of gin; I afterwards came back, and I a pint of 6d. ale; the money found on me I honestly worked for; my never paid me with a sovereign.
(Welch received a good character.)

GUILTY on 2nd and 3rd Counts—
Confined Six Months each.

1132.
GEORGE PRITCHARD was indicted
for a like offence.
MR. CLERK. conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES WILLIAM BAKER . I keep the William the Fourth beer house, Old Kent Road. On 19th Oct., about five minutes before 10 o'clock, the prisoner came for a pint of porter and put down a counterfeit shilling——I broke it in two with my mouth, and asked him to pay for the porter—he said that he had not got any more money—I marked the pieces and put them on the counter—he took them away, and I took back my beer—this (produced) is one of the pieces.

JOSEPH BROWN . I keep the Builders' Arms, Bermondsey New Road, not two minutes walk from Mr. Baker's. On 19th Oct., about 10 o'clock, the prisoner came for half a pint of, porter, and gave me a shilling—Mr. Baker had sent a man, who came in behind him and said, "Look at that shilling; he has just come from Mr. Baker's "—I tried it; it was bad, and I give him into custody.

JOHN BRYANT . (Policeman, M 212). I took the prisoner—Mr. Brown gave me this shilling (produced)—I searched him in the house, but I found nothing—on the way to the station he said, "I expect I shall get remanded, and then get turned up;" that means discharged—on the following morn
ing, about six o'clock, I searched between Mr. Baker's house and Mr. Brown's, and picked up this piece of a broken shilling on the pavement.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad shilling; and this is a fragment of another.
Prisoner's Defence. I was at Mr. Brown's house, but I know nothing of the piece which was picked up; I may have taken it When I was out with or barrow.

GUILTY . ** †—
Confined Twelve Months.

1133.
EDWARD DAVIS (17),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Samuel Spencer, at
St. George the Martyr, Southwark and stealing therein one clock, one sheet, one candlestick, and one tobacco box, value 17s. 6d., his property.

REBECCA SPENCER . I am the wife of Samuel Spencer, of No. 5 Alford Place, Old Kent Road, in the parish of St. George, Southwark; it is his dwelling house. On 8th Sep. I fastened up the house about 10 minutes to 11 o'clock; all the windows and doors were safe; the kitchen window was shut down, but I cannot say whether it was fastened I placed this pair of trowsers (produced) op a chair in front of the fire, as they were damp, and I looked up and saw this candlestick and tobacco box safe—I was not disturbed in the night, but missed the things in the morning.

MARY FOOT . I live with Mrs. Spencer. I came down at half past 5 o'clock, and found the kitchen window partly open, and the kitchen and garden doors—there is no shutter; the bolt of the garden door was not broken—I cannot say whether there was any fastening to the window; if anybody opened it they could get in—I informed Mrs. Spencer, who came down.

EDWARD JOHNSON . (Policeman, P 40). I stopped the prisoner with these articles, at about half past 5 o'clock in the morning, a very short distance from the house—I asked him how he became in possession of the bundle—said, "I am going to No. 7, round the corner, with it"—I said, "Where did you bring it from?"—he said, "I found it" I said, "Where?" he said, "Down there," pointing to a turning by a fence in the rear of the prosecutor's house—I said, "Come and show me where you found it"—he took me down the turning, and pointed to a cart shed, saying, "I found it there," in a yard adjoining the shed—I said, "What caused you to come down here?"—he said, "I was passing down the top, and saw the bundle lying there, and came down to fetch it"—it is not a thoroughfare, and it is impossible for anybody to see from the top to where he pointed to—I asked him where he lived; he said, "I live here"—I said, "Where?" he pointed to a house at the bottom—I said, "Do not tell an untruth; I will call the parties up and see"—he said, "Well, I used to live there"—I said, "Where do you live?" and he said, "In East Lane"—I asked him where—he said, "Mason Street"—I asked the number; he said, "21" or "26"—I found that his father lived at 26, and had forbidden him the house in consequence of his bad conduct—I took him into custody.
REBECCA SPENCER . (re-examined). These are the articles.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to work, and saw the policeman ten yards ahead of me; I work at Kingdon and Powell's, and go there at 6 o'clock; the policeman walked down the turning, and walked on and talked to another policeman; then went down and picked it up, and as I turned the corner, the policeman stopped me.

GUILTY . *—
Four Years Penal Servitude.

1134.
MARY ANN BROWN (16),
Stealing 2 perambulators, value 34s., the property of
Eliza Thorns.

ELIZA THOMS . I live with my mother at No. 1, Durham Place, Lambeth Road; she lets out perambulators—I know the prisoner. On 6th Oct. she came to No. 1, Durham Place—she wished to hire a perambulator for a lodger of Miss Smith, No. 6, Webber Row, Westminster Road—she did not say who Miss Smith's lodger was—I let her have a perambulator—she also said she wished to have another one after tea—she came after tea, and I let her have another—she said she would bring them home together—she did not bring them—I did not see her until the Friday after, at the corner of Kennington Road—I caught hold of her, and asked her where my perambulators were—she said she had not seen them, and she knew nothing of them—I am quite sure she is the person—the value of the perambulators was 1l. 14s.

MARY CASH . I am fourteen years old—I live in the same house as Miss Thoms—I was present when the prisoner came and hired the perambulators—I am quite sure she is the person—she hired both the perambulators at the same time—she said a lodger in the house wanted one after tea, could she have one—I saw her take away the second—mistress sent me to look after the perambulator—I watched the prisoner, and she kept looking behind her—I watched her as far as Tower Street—I waited a moment—she went down Waterloo Road, and took up a child and put her in the chaise, and said to me, "Now you see it is all right"—she said she would acquaint my mistress when she brought it home.

JAMES BRADLEY . (Policeman, L 93). I took the prisoner into cus
tody—she said it was the prosecutrix's mistake, she was not the person.

GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy on account of her youth.—
Judgment Respited

1135.
CORNELIUS REILLY (39),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

1136.
THOMAS BROADWOOD (23), was indicted
for a like offence: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

1137.
CHARLES MARTIN ,
THOMAS BARKER , and
JOSEPH JAMES ,
Stealing 100 gallons of oil, value 15l., the goods of
William Gardner, the master of Martin and Barker.
MESSRS. METCALFE. and SALTER. conducted the Prosecution.

PETER WHITT . I am mate on board the Pollux steam vessel. On 16th Sept. we had on board 32 casks of linseed oil—I took them in at Hamburgh—when we arrived at London they were put into a barge—I do not recollect the name of it—I noticed the casks at the time I took them out—I did not see any spile holes in them at that time—they are usually at the top or bottom of the cask—I did not notice any such holes as these(Looking at some spile holes in the head of a cask) at the time they left the vessel—I cannot recollect seeing either of the prisoners in the barge.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Was this separation in the head of a cask when it left? A. No; I did not look for spile holes—some casks were leaky, not very leaky—there was one cask that had not much oil in it; I cannot tell how much—I saw that they had been leaking—the casks were put into the barge with slings—we generally use sling whether the cash are good or bad—I saw that the oil had been leaking from those casks—I examined the hold afterwards; I did not find any quantity of oil there.
COURT. Q. How long had the casks been in that hold? A. About five days.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. How many casks were moved into the barge? A. Thirty-two—about ten men were assisting in moving them from the Pollux into the barge—they were lifted up by machinery, and slung down into the barge—they were rolled into the barge—the next cask would knock against the other—we took them on board at Hamburgh—I do not know where we got them from—I cannot tell whether the casks were full; I did not examine them—we were five days in coming—it was not during the equinoctial gales—we had a good passage—it was not blowing hard—it was at Horselydown that we moved the casks from the Pollux into the barge—our vessel was 250 tons—we had a general cargo.

ROBERT HENRY MORGAN . I am a tide surveyor. On 16th Sept. I was on duty on board the Pollux steamer—I saw a number of casks of linseed oil—I examined four of them—I found them sound—I do not know whether the others were sound or not—I saw the whole of them—I did not observe any unsoundness, except in one cask, which was leaking at the head very much—it was leaking round the chine at the edge—there was no leakage from spile holes like these—I called attention to that particular cask—I saw some of the casks put into the barge, perhaps four or five—I did not see any of those leak, only the one—I mentioned to the mate to put it in a
certain position, with the head upwards, or it would leak all out, and it was put so.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did you go into the barge? A. Yes—I do not remember how they were packed in the barge—I do not remem
ber whether they were all in the bottom of the barge or not—I selected four of them, and made a full examination of them, to see if there was any in them subject to duty—I ascertained what was in them by taking bung out and putting a stick in—I did not make any spile holes.

WILLIAM GARDNER . I am a lighterman, and live in Horselydown. The barge Miskin was in my employ—on 15th Sept. I gave directions that it should be taken to the Pollux to take the oil—Martin was my foreman.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Was it a barge that was hired? A. Yes—Martin has been in my employ fifteen months—I believed him to be a man of good character—I know nothing against his character—he had no authority to hire anybody.

THOMAS TOON . I am foreman to Messrs. Wheeler and Co., wharfingers, at Casson's Wharf. On 18th Sept. I remember a number of casks of oil coming to the dock—I noticed them, and I observed there were spile holes, and they were leaking—the spile holes were at the head part, at either end—a great many of them appeared to have been recently made—they had been made with a common sized gimlet—I gave directions to have the whole of the casks weighed—there were thirty-two casks.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You gave directions to two persons to clean the barge out? A. Yes—I first saw it on Friday, 18th Sept., about 5 or 6 o'clock in the evening—I did not see any one with the barge—it was on the side of the wharf—it was brought there on Friday evening, and left there—it had not been there more than half an hour—I had been there all day backwards and forwards—I came back, and saw the barge—I had left the same place about an hour—there was nobody with the barge—it remained till the next morning.

WILLIAM TILLEY . I live at No. 5, King Street, Horselydownn; I am in the employ of Messrs. Wheeler and Co. On 19th Sept. a lighter came to me to be unloaded—I noticed the casks in it—several casks were leaking from great spile holes—I noticed spile holes in nine or ten casks, and there was a good drop of oil in the barge—I was ordered to go down and scoop the oil up and put it into a cask—there was water with it—I got up some
where about 100 gallons of oil and water together—I cannot tell what quantity of water there was—we scooped up all the oil we could find on the top of the water—when we got it into the cask there was much water with it—the oil was on the top of the water—I saw the barge taken away by Shorter—before that I had cleared all the oil I could see—the cabin was shut, and there was a padlock on the door—I did not look inside the cabin.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Was there not any hole that you could look through into the cabin? A. No—I mean to swear there was a lock on tie cabin—I did not try it—I was not anxious to get into the cabin—I saw there was a padlock on it—I swept the bottom of the barge—I did not take up the floor—I was never under the boards of the barge.
JOHN JAMES RICKMAN . I was with the last witness when he was scooping up the oil—I did not notice the cabin door—I did not see the barge till Saturday.

WILLIAM PATTISON . I am in the employ of Messrs. Wheeler and Co—I did not see the oil come—I noticed ten of the casks had spile holes, which were open—some spile holes were filled up, and some were not—some

had been put in previous to their coming to the scale—I took the weights—I have a copy of it here, 35, 023 lbs.—I found one cask in which wag a great deficiency, No. 164; it was not a quarter fall—there were two spile holes in the head of the cask, and one spile hole in the quarter—these holes had been stopped up—it was a sound cask independent of the spile holes—it did not appear to have leaked from any other part—ten casks were not full.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You examined the whole of the casks? A. Yes—I found one cask leaking from the head, and that one was get up on the end—there might have been about 5 cwt. in that cask, and that cask might hold about 14 cwt.—it was about one-third full—I will swear there was more than 2 cwt. or 3 cwt. in it—one cask we looked at had only about half it should have had, provided it had been full.

DANIEL BALSON . On 19th Sept. I saw thirty-two casks of oil on the wharf—some had holes in them, and they were very shakey casks, and leak
ing at both ends—there were spile holes in them—I think I perceived spile holes in about eight of them—they were in the head—two of the holes in one cask had spiles in them, the others had not—I stopped them up with spiles.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. A. What do you mean by shakey? A. They were in a bad state—I am in the service of Messrs. Wheeler—the casks were taken out of the barge by slings—that is usual when they are not in good condition—when they are, they are taken out with the hooks—I noticed some casks leaking besides those with the spiles—there might be six or seven leaking from natural causes—they had been old wine pipes before.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Would those which were leaking without the spile holes leak as much as 200 gallons? A. Ye, more than that in the barge—I do not know how long they were in the barge.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Do you mean that the casks might have leaked 200 gallons from what injury you saw they had sustained, independent of the spile holes? A. Yes, from the slightness of the casks—there was a little got out by Toon—there might be 16 cwt. or 17 cwt.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. You say these casks were wine casks? A. They seemed so—they were not new—how many times they had been used in the wine trade I do not know.

EDWARD EVEREST . (Themes police inspector). On Sunday, 20th Sept, I was on duty in my boat about half past 11 o'clock. I saw the prisoner Barker on board the Miskin barge, at Bermondsey, about 400 yards from Pearson's wharf—he was scooping up oil, and placing it in two small casks, about seven or eight gallons each—I went on board the barge—one or two of the floor boards were taken, up, and he was scooping the oil from between the timbers of the barge—I asked him what he was doing—he said "Scoop
ing up some oil"—I asked him what authority he had to scoop it up—he said, "Martin gave it me"—I asked him what authority Martin had to give it him, and he said he did not know—I left a constable in charge of him, and I went to another barge close by, where I found a cask containing about ten gallons of the same description of oil—I came back to the Miskin barge in about ten minutes afterwards, and I found all the three prisoners there—I found in the cabin three larger casks, and three cans full of oil—I asked Barker what he had done with the oil he landed in the morning—he said he had sold it to Harradine—I asked how much there was—he said, "About twenty-four gallons"—I asked if there was any one there who had tad part of that with him, and James made answer, "Yes, Martin"—Martin made answer, "Yes; I gave it to him, it is only drainings; it is an

every day occurrence"—the cabin was open when I went—when I took Barker I took a key from him which he said he had had to lock the cabin—I then went to Mr. Gardner, and Martin went with me—Mr. Gardner came back with us, and I took James and Barker into custody—in the afternoon, I went to Harradine's house about half past 3 o'clock—he is a marine store dealer—I there found two ten gallon cans full of oil, and a cask holding from thirty to thirty-six gallons besides—there was very little water mixed with it, and very little dirt—I have samples from the different places—this one is from that that was in the cask at Mr. Harradine's—this is from the cans found on board the barge—this other is from the cask on board the barge—I found seventy gallons on board the barge, and fifty-two gallons at Harradine's—I went to James's house on Sunday night, and he met me at the door—I told him I wanted to see what he had got in his house—I went in, and saw Martin sitting there—he said, "Halloo! Mr. Everest, I have just come to have an understanding about this oil"—I satisfied myself that there was no oil on the premises, and I called Martin out and took him into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You first saw Barker? A. Yes; I do not know that in consequence of what I said Martin was fetched—James lives about ten minutes' walk from there—I asked if any one had had part, and James said, "Yes, it was only drainings, it is an every day occurrence."

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. On what day did you see James? A. On Sunday, about half past 1 o'clock—I was at his house the same night about 8 o'clock—he had been bailed out by the inspector—Martin is fore
man to Mr. Gardner—I took Martin into custody, and he went down to the station—he did not say that he knew nothing about it, and he was only acting under direction—there was about seventy gallons found on board—there had been a good deal of leakage, being old casks.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You found some oil on board another barge? A. Yes; about ten gallons—the barge was all saturated with oil—the barge would not require a great deal of cleaning.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Do you really mean to pledge your oath that James did not say to you words to this effect, that Martin had given him authority to remove the oil? A. No; the only answer he made when I asked if any person had any part of that was, "Yes, Martin"—I took him on the Miskin barge—I told him I should take him into custody for having possession of the oil.
JAMES HARRADINE . I live at No. 88, Dockhead. I gave up the cans of oil to the police—I received them from James and Barker, on 19th Sept., about half past 4 o'clock—I paid 1s. 6d. a gallon for it.

WILLIAM GARDNER . re-examined. Martin was my foreman—I know nothing of James—it would be part of my foreman's duty to superintend the cargo of oil—he would not have to pay for the barge—the bill would come to me—I have not carried much oil; two or three parcels in three months—they are all carried in barges—the Miskin may have had other cargoes of oil in it—I have not received the bill yet—the owner of the barge is Henry Dug
gan—I never had oil conveyed in his barge before—my men would not have any right to take any leakage—if there had been a small leakage of two or three gallons I should take no notice of it—I do not claim any leakage—that leakage would be such as would not be worth the consignee's notice—if a barge is hired and it gets into a mess with leakage I should not have to clean it, I should return it in it's dirty state—if the men had informed me
that 100 gallons of oil was left in the barge I should have referred it to the wharfinger.
(Martin and James received good characters.)

MARTIN—
NOT GUILTY .

BARKER—
GUILTY .—
Four Tears Penal Servitude.

JAMES—
GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
—
Confined Twelve Months.

1138.
GEORGE COX ,
Embezzling 6l. 10s. and 6l. 6s., the moneys of
Lawrence Earnshaw and others.
MR. GIFFARD. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM MORRIS . I am an engineer—the prisoner was in the employ of a society, of which I am a member, called the British Engineers' Benefit Society—it is a registered friendly society—it was part of his duty to receive money on behalf of that society—in the event of his receiving cheques, it was his duty to pay them into our bankers, the London and Westminster Bank—I have the account he made out—I know his writing—this is his writing—here is no entry in this statement of 6l. 6s. paid by Mr. Hall, on the 28th May, or of 6l. 10s. paid by Mr. Hopkinson, on the 26th of May—this account goes down to June.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Was the prisoner secretary to this society? A. Yes, and he was also a subscriber, and had been so for four years and upwards—there were quarrels and misunderstandings between the members—in the course of these quarrels some of the books were taken from the prisoner—I do not remember what books they were—I know that he had received directions to pay over money to the auditors, from time to time—the auditors were Parker, McBride, Sprey, and Rowe—I have heard that the prisoner paid money to those men in May—the opposite side of this account shows that the auditors received certain sums—the prisoner had authority from the executive council to pay those auditors—Mr. Williamson is chairman of the auditors.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Had he any authority to pay cheques to the auditors? A. No—I was not at all aware that he had received those cheques—he went to Dartford for one—I discovered that some time after—he did not tell me—I had no communication with him.
MR. LILLEY. Q. IS this book in the writing of the prisoner? A. Yes—I have every reason to believe that this entry, where the leaf is turned down, is his writing.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. Do you know anything about this book? A. No, I never saw it before.
JOHN HOPKINSON . I am an engineer, and a member and subscriber to this society—on 26th May, I paid the prisoner a check for 6l. 10s.—it has been returned to me from my bankers as paid.

EDWARD HALL . I am an engineer, and live at Dartford. I am a sub
scriber to the Engineers' Benefit Society—on 28th May, I paid the prisoner a cheque of 6l. 6s. for the benefit of the society—it has been returned to me from Messrs. Lubbock and Co.
HENRY ROSE . I am a clerk in the London and County Bank—Messrs. Hopkinson keep an account at that bank—on 26th May I paid cash for this cheque over the counter—I do not know who presented it.

THOMAS JAMES BRAY . I am a clerk in the Bank of Messrs. Lubbock. Mr. Hall has an account at our bank—on 29th May I gave cash for this cheque—it is dated the 28th—it has not passed through the London and Westminster Bank—it was paid over the counter.
LAYTON ASHTON . I am a clerk in the London and Westminster Bank. The British Engineers' Benefit Society keeps an account at that bank—these two cheques have not passed through that bank.

THOMAS PARKER . I was one of the auditors of that society. The prisoner had authority to pay me money as an auditor—he had not authority to pay me cheques—it was his duty to pay them into our bankers.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been an auditor? A. I am not by profession an auditor—I acted as an auditor to this society—we were sitting about fifteen days—I was acting with Mr. Sprey and others—during that sitting the prisoner paid various sums of money—we commenced sitting on Monday, May 18th, and sat till the 3rd June.

Q. Were the sums which are mentioned on this side of this account paid to you, begin at the 26th May, and go on? A. I have a perfect recollection of a portion of these being paid—I cannot say whether the others were paid—there were four of us sat, and we had 11s. a day—Mr. Williamson was our chairman—I believe he had the same as we had—I believe the prisoner paid me—supposing cash were paid to us we did not inquire whether it was the result of cheques or not, but we were perfectly well aware where the cash came from—we were aware that we received moneys.
COURT. Q. Are the 6l. 6s. and the 6l. 10s. in this account? A. No.

MR. LILLEY. Q. Will you look at this paper: was that submitted to you as an auditor? A. No, Sir, these items were never submitted to the auditors—we were only auditing the accounts of last year, not the present year—I heard from the prisoner that he had received these cheques of 6l. 6s. and 6l. 10s. and paid them in—I have not heard from him that he had paid over the money in the payments he made to the auditors—I am not aware at all that he did—I could not undertake to swear that he did not—at the commencement of the audit, 30l. odd was advanced for the expenses of the trustees—probably the 30l. was exhausted about the 26th of May, but there was other money advanced from the various branches to pay the expenses—Mr. Williamson was the chairman—I do not recollect that he directed that these two cheques of 6l. 6s. or 6l. 10s. should be cashed—he might give such directions, but not in my presence, nor in the presence of the auditors.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. When was it the prisoner told you he had received these cheques and paid them in? A. When he returned from Dartford he told us he had received the cheque, and also when he returned from Messrs. Hopkinson he told us he had received their cheque—I did not ask him what he had done with them—I thought he would pay them into our bankers.
WILLIAM HOWE . (Police sergeant, M 19). I took the prisoner on the 17th of September.

Cross-examined. Q. You told him the charge was embezzling money? A. Yes; his reply was, "Not that I am aware of"—a smaller sum was mentioned, and he said, not that he was aware of—when at the station he said he could not enter it in his books, because his books were taken from him in March last—he said, "I have no doubt I entered it in the minute book, I generally enter it there."
MR. GIFFARD. Q. Another sum was mentioned, what was that? A. 2l.; there was no date given—I found on him a memorandum and four blank cheques.
THOMAS PARKER . (re-examined). Q. You heard from the prisoner that he had received these cheques and paid them in? A. I understood that he
had paid them into the London and Westminster Bank—I never saw this book before (looking at one)—I never Was aware that it was a petty cash book.

CHARLES VICKERS . I am a member of this society, and have bean so three years or more. I have known the prisoner all the time acting as general secretary—more than half the time I have been one of the executive council for the Lambeth branch, I believe for two years—during all that time the prisoner has had the character of an honest, upright man; a man more respected I never knew—he gave notice that he would leave the society as secretary, and he was retained again—there have been differences in the society between the members for the last four or five months—I have seen this little book in possession of the prisoner—he told me it belonged to the society—I first saw it in Sept.—I was asking the prisoner to give me a sheet of paper of the expenses of the auditors; he said, "I have not got the list done"—he said he had the account of all, and then I saw this book—he said, "They have taken the books, and this book has got the account"—the prisoner was not in custody at the time I saw this book—I saw it the first week in September—I had not seen it previously to that—I saw the entries which the book contained, because I wanted the account to show to my branch—it is in my knowledge, that in consequence of the differences the prisoner had not access to the whole of the books—I understood this book belonged to the society; it is a cash book-no charge of this kind had been made against the prisoner at the time I saw this book.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Had no charge of embezzlement been made against him at that time? A. No, I swear there was not—I do not remember the date when it was,—there was a charge made by the auditors that there was something wrong—that was before I saw this book-—it was not in con
sequence of that charge that I asked for the book—it was to give information to my branch—I did not look to try to find some accounts of the receipt of the money that Mr. Hall had paid—I was told this was one of the society's books—it was before August that the prisoner was asked to give up the books belonging to the society—I forget the date when this book was bought—it was when he came from Sidney Smith's office—I do not know where it was bought—I believe I saw the account furnished by the prisoner on this register—I did not look if there was any account of these sum it—there were differences in the society for five or six months—that had reference to the disappearance of money; what the auditors called deficiency—they said various sums were deficient one time and various sums at another; but they contradicted themselves several times—they said some
times 100l. and sometimes 40l.—I was not at the Police Court when the prisoner was under examination.

MR. LILLEY. Q. Were you requested to attend? A. No; the prisoner had not access to the books of the society down to the time of this charge—I cannot recollect the date when he ceased to have access to the books, but I know they were taken away from there in a most abrupt manner, by men who had elected themselves—the prisoner continued to act as secretary down to the time of his apprehension, he continued to act after the books were taken from him—he said he would give up, but they requested him to continue as secretary.

DAVID WILLIAMSON . I am chairman of the executive council. On 26th May, I accompanied the prisoner to the bank to cask a cheque for 6l. 10s.—this is it—I was along with him when he received these cheques and when he cashed them—I gave no consent to his cashing the cheques, I only went

with him—on that, after receiving the money, he paid me 11s. as my salary as auditor, and on that day, after he had obtained cash for the cheques, he paid the auditors somewhere about 3l. 6s. 6d.—on the 27th, I believe he paid 3l. 6s. 6d. and on the 28th, I believe he paid 3l. 8s. 1d.—he has been in the habit of paying all along.

Q. Did he pay somebody for making reports 1l. 1s.? A. I believe then was something to that effect—I am not aware of the amount he paid on the 29th—he paid some on the 30th—he did not pay me 1l. 10s. on the 30th—I did not receive that sum, I received 11s.—I do not keep any account of the money received, I am speaking from memory—I will under. take to say I did not receive that amount on that day—I have been the chairman of the executive council since the beginning of the present year—I had been once or twice before—I have not known of cheques being cashed without being paid into the bank—the prisoner has been secretary four years—I have not known anything against him—I am not aware of a movement to bring him back to the society when he was about to retire.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Do not you know it was his duty to pay cheques into the bankers: how came you to go with him to get these cheques cashed? A. He told me he wanted money for the society—I never saw this book before to-day—I was appointed to be chairman by the executive council.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

1139.
HENRY CHENERY was indicted
for embezzlement.
MR. ROBINSON. conducted the Prosecution.

HERBERT STURMEY . I am secretary and clerk to the trustees of the Borough Market. We have, under our Act of Parliament, to collect the tolls from persons coming to the market—up to 1855, we had been in the habit of letting the tolls—at that time the trustees took them into their own hands, and the prisoner was appointed collector of the tolls—he went on acting as collector for the next twelve months—it was his duty to enter the tolls as he received them, in a book, and from week to week to produce that book to a local committee, and at the end of the month to produce that book to me, in order that I might enter the proceeds in the cash book of the trustees, and produce the book at the monthly meeting of the trustees, held on the first Friday in every month—it was his duty to pay the money into the bank weekly, and to produce that book also to the local committee, to show that the money had been paid in—this is the book in which he made the entries of money received, and this is the bankers' book—the prisoner commenced collecting in June, 1856, and he went on collecting till June 24th, 1857.

HENRY MONK . I am a fruit salesman. I was in the habit of paying the prisoner the tolls for the fruit brought into the Borough Market. I recol
