lect paying him the amounts of these three papers—I was not in the habit of taking receipts, but merely a cross on the bills—I paid him the amounts of these three bills, 25th Aug., 1l. 2s. 7d.; 1st Sept., 1l. 10s. 6d.; and 11th Sept., 1l. 12s. 0½d., amounting to 4l. 5s. 1½d.—I do not know the date; it was near 27th Sept.—I have seen the prisoner since June, 1857—he requested me to destroy some of those bills—I cannot say when it was; it was several times.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Have you known him many years? A. Yes; he was beadle of the market fifteen years, and collector of the tools—he held both situations—there are a great many persons in that market—he has to collect from a great number of persons.

HERBERT STURMEY . re-examined. Q. Turn to the prisoner's account up to the date of the last of these bills, amounting to 4l. 5s. 1½d. what has he entered in his book for the week ending 30th Aug.? A. "Mr. Monk, 12s. 11d." for the week ending 6th Sept., 19s. 7d.; and for the week end
ing 13th Sept., 17s. 11d.; total, 2l. 10s. 5d.—I have the bankers' book here, and the amounts paid in correspond with the entries in this book.

Cross-examined. Q. He had the office of beadle, and took upon himself to collect for the market? A. Yes—he can write—it was his duty to pay the money into the bank weekly, the amount of money he received—he had not authority to make any disbursements—I am not aware that he made any. unless it was by the express sanction of the local committee—if he made petty disbursements, it would be by the express sanction of that committee-—this is the toll book in which he made his entries—I cannot tell in whose writing the entries in this book are; I believe they are not his—the names here are of the persons from whom he received tolls—here is 2l. 11s. 4d. and 1l. 9s. 4d.; I suppose they would be Sunday tolls—here is "Sundries," that would be casual tolls from some persons in the public market—I believe all these would be tolls—I rather think the writing in this book is one of the prisoner's sons—when he was taken into custody, I do not know whether any intimation was given him that we were about to do so-—I was in the country—I believe he was before the committee to go through the accounts, and to give explanations—no other person was engaged in collecting the tolls by my authority—I believe his sons did not assist him; certainly not, within my knowledge.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. There were persons who had regular stands? A. Yes; and the persons whose names are in the book are regular stand holders, and the others are casual stands.
BENJAMIN ALBIN TOMKINS . I am one of the trustees. The prisoner had to account to us from time to time, and to produce the book.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

1140.
HENRY CHENERY was again indicted
for embezzlement.
MR. ROBINSON. conducted the Prosecution.

HENRY MONK . I have a stall in the Borough Market About 16th March, I paid the prisoner 13s. 11 1/2 d.—it was about then, I will not under
take to say it was on that date—about 28th March, I paid him 1l. 13s. 4d.; and on 4th April, 14s. 7d.—I saw the prisoner after 24th June; he said he wished me to destroy some of the bills, he said I could do it very easily.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. How did this conversation arise be
tween you? A. He came to the counting house, and asked me to do it—it was after the 24th of June in this year—I cannot say exactly what time—I took no notice of it—I am almost sure it was after the 24th: I cannot exactly say whether it was in June or July—there was no one present but him and me—I have mentioned it to two or three in the market.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. He gave up the toll on the 24th June, and was it after that? A. Yes.
HERBERT STURMEY . I am solicitor to the trustees of the Borough Market.

(The evidence given by this witness in the last case was read by the COURT, which the witness stated was correct)—in the book for the entries of these accounts, for the week ending 21st March, here is "Mr. Monk, 1s. 5d. "—for the week ending 28th March, 12s. 6d.; and for the week ending 4th April, 5s. 1d.—I have examined the bankers' book, and that corresponds with these amounts.
Cross-examined. Q. What amount did he receive in the aggregate on

the week ending 21st March? A. 1l. 9s. 11d.; and sundries, 1l. 1s. on the week ending 28th March, 2l. 6s. 4d.; and sundries, 1l. 6s. the week ending 4th April, 21. 3s. 10d.; and sundries, 1l. 11s. 4d.—these other items are wagon rates, they are a different account; on 21st March, 8l. odd; on 28th, 9l. odd; and on 4th April, 8l. odd.

Q. Have you not found under the head of sundries large amounts? A. I have not calculated them—I believe the prisoner was not taken till Sept.—a committee was sitting a month or more on the accounts—I was present once—I know the prisoner had not been summoned then.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. The large items are entered in another book? A. Yes, the particulars of them are entered in another book.

BENJAMIN ALBIN TOMKINS . I recollect the prisoner being called before a committee appointed to consider what remuneration he should have for his collecting the tolls—the committee was appointed soon after 24th June, and they adjourned from time to time—I think the discovery of these defal
cations was made at our first meeting in July—we went through the accounts and made inquiries—the result was communicated to the prisoner at the first meeting, which I believe was in July; he was called in, and the subject was mentioned of defalcations, or a discrepancy in his book—his reply was, "All the money that I have received I have paid in"—I was not at that time fully aware of these matters that are inquired about now; not of my own knowledge—we proceeded to make inquiries—the prisoner was in attend
ance at the meeting of the committee—I believe he was outside the door—he attended the meetings of the committee and sub-committees—he was eventually given into custody.
NOT GUILTY .

1141.
JOHN BROOKS (27),
HARRIET PEACH (21), and
CAROLINE RICHARDSON (38),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
John Coleman, at Camberwell, and stealing 228l. in money, his property.
MR. POLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN COLEMAN . I live at Church Street, Highgate. On 1st Sept. I kept the King's Head, Meeting House Lane, Peckham—on that evening I went up into my bed room, at a little after 6 o'clock, and saw a box safe with 100 sovereigns in it, also a canvas bag with 100 or 102 sovereigns, and three 5l. notes, with eight sovereigns rolled up in them, and two 5l. notes loose—I locked the door, but left the key in it—I had occasion to go to the drawer about half past 9 o'clock for some papers, and found the door wide open, the drawer broken open with a chisel, and the money gone, and the box except the lid—the blind of the front window was right up; there were no marks on it—there is a yard at the back of the house to the skittle ground, and a passage four or five feet wide—there is no difficulty in getting up from there to the window—a boy six years old could get up—there are two water butts, then the slates, then some wood work and a trough, and the back room window is about so high from the slates: that window was thrown open—there were footmarks across the bed, as if a person had come across it, and a chisel on it—a very small piece of candle was thrown on the front room bed—there is a yard at the back of the house, and a gate leading from there to the passage, at the end of which there is a very large lamp, and another at the front door—the door leading from the passage to the yard is always left open for people to go to the skittle ground—on that night I saw Brooks there—I had seen him there for a month previous, and in the skittle ground—I have frequently seen Richardson at my house, but cannot say whether I saw her

or Peach there that night—there were many people at the bar, but there was no one playing at skittles—I have seen Brooks and Richardson together before, but cannot say as to Peach—I have the resemblance of her.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. How long had you had this money in the house? A. Some of it over a month; it was what I had taken daily, and what I had to pay to my collector—I do not keep a banking account—my potman is not here; he knows nothing about it—I do not keep a barmaid—my wife knew that I had money in the drawer, but nobody knew the quantity—I had the number of the notes, and they have been stopped—the name of "R. Holloway" was on one of them—it was discovered that they had been paid in to somebody—there are not persons playing at I skittles every night—my potman attends to the skittle ground, but I know I there was no playing that night, for I had the key of the skittle ground in the bar—I always keep it locked till it is wanted—I gave evidence before the Magistrate next day—Brooks was not found then—policeman named Cox was there, but I do not know that he was in custody for that, only for a few words that he had said--l gave the evidence I have given to-day, but not against Cox—I do not think it was on 3rd Sept.—Cox was charged with saying that if he had had time that day he should be able to find out the man and the money—he was put at the bar alone while I was giving my evidence, but not for the robbery, only for saying that; but it was a romance that he made use of, it had no meaning in it—I was ordered to go to the station by Sergeant Bond, who told me Cox was in custody for making use of that observation—Coat has been in the habit of coming to my house two or three months—I did hot see him there on the night of the robbery; he may have been—he may have looked into the parlour at about 9 o'clock and said, "You look all comfortable; I will not disturb you"—I heard a person there say that, and they said that it was Cox, but I cannot say that it was—I do not know his voice—I saw him next morning, between 8 and 9 o'clock, and he said, in reference to the robbery, "What a bad job it is"—that was on the 2nd, and on the 3rd he was in custody, but I did not give him into custody—I swear that I saw Brooks at my house on the night of the robbery—I have never been asked the question before, but was always as certain of it as I am now—you will find that what I said on the 8th was just the same as I say now—I cannot say what Brown was doing, because I did not attend to the bar, but I saw him as I came from the parlour into my kitchen—my wife and my two boys of thirteen and fourteen were serving; they are not here—if he is convicted, I expect to get any money found in his possession.
MR. POLAND. Q. When Cox was taken, were you directed to attend before the Magistrate? A. Yes did so, and he was discharged—my house is in the parish of St. Giles, Camberwell.

ANN LAITE . I am the wife of Thomas Laite, of No. 6, Meeting House lane, Peckham, directly opposite the King's Head. On Tuesday evening, 1st Sept., about 9 o'clock, I was at my window, and saw a man, with a light in his hand, come into Mr. Coleman's front bed room, on the first floor—he had a cap on; I cannot say the colour of it, but he wore it straight on his head—I only saw his side face—I went down to the station where Brooks was in custody; there were two or three other people there, and I pointed to Brooks, and said, "That is the man in every particular, but I cannot swear to him, because I did not see his full face"—the light was not in the room more than five minutes—my husband was sitting at the window; the blind was down at the top.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. How far across is it? A. Directly opposite—I did not think it was a robbery—I said, "There is a light in Mr. Coleman's room, and a man there with a cap on; "my husband turned his head, and said, "Yes"—the other men that I saw at the station were not dressed at all like Brooks; they had black coats on, they were not in labourer's clothes—I said, "I think he is the man, he is more like the man than any man I ever saw before "—two or three men had been shown to me before—I did not know Cox—I swear to Brooks now.

THOMAS LAITE . I was at my window, getting my supper; my wife called my attention, and I looked out, and saw a man in Mr. Coleman's front room, close against the drawers, with a light in his hand—I believe Brooks to be the man—he had a lightish cap, with spots—I saw his side face—I had not known him before—it was a cap much like this (produced) but I do not believe this is it, it may be.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you say you do not think it is the cap? A. Well, I did, but I should say that it is; I was looking at the peak of it, and I do not think I saw the peak hanging down—I mean to say that Brooks is the man—I am certain that I saw him up there, but I did not know him, because he had his whiskers shaved off, but he has more whiskers now, and therefore I am certain of him—I am more certain of him than I am of the cap—I have said that I should not like to swear to him.
MR. POLAND. Q. What time was it? A. About 9 o'clock—the cap had a peak, and I just saw it hang over a little bit.

ROBERT GOSLING . I live in Meeting House Lane, Peckham, at the back of the King's Head. On Tuesday, 1st Sept., I went out about 8 o'clock or half past, and saw Richardson in the passage leading from my house to Mr. Coleman's, coming out of his back gate—there is a gas lamp four or five yards from the gate—I went into my house, and stopped about a quarter of an hour, then came out, and saw Peach, I believe, standing there, with a red shawl on, leaning against an iron fence—I cannot swear to her being the person—I stood there for about a quarter of an hour, waiting for a little boy of mine, and then saw Brooks in the passage—the roadway and the path there measures eighteen feet.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you examined more than once? A. Only once; it was on Brooks's trial—I was not examined when he was first in custody—a policeman came on a Saturday night, to ask me to give evidence—he said that he had got a man in custody, and asked me if I did not think there was a woman concerned, and I said, "Yes"—he asked me if I thought I should be able to identify the man—I said I thought so—a sergeant gave me a summons to appear, and I went, and saw him brought before the bar; he was alone, and I told the Magistrate that, to the best of my belief, he was the man—I was not certain, because he had a different dress on—that was some days after he was taken—I believe he has the same clothes on now that he had when he came out of Mr. Coleman's house.

Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Q. Did you say before the Magistrate that it was at 10 minutes past 8 o'clock? A. I will not be positive; I think it was nearer the half hour—I know it was 1st Sept., because I had a letter from my wife; my daughter brought it to me when we met Richardson—I was afterwards taken to the station, and saw her there; there were two other women present.
MARY GREENFIELD . I live with my husband, at 1, Meeting House Lane, Peckham, about five doors from the King's Head. On 1st Sept.,

about half past 8 o'clock at night, I saw Richardson pass and repass twice—when I first saw her, she was coming from the king's Head, and then she passed me and turned round the corner, and came back again and went towards the King's Head—I went to the King's Head to fetch a pint of beer, and saw her standing at the bar, drinking a glass of gin—she had a light coloured shawl.
Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Is it a dark lane? A. No, quite light—I had not seen her before—I did not see her again till she was in custody, on 19th Oct.

THOMAS EVANS . (Policeman, G 145). I received information of this rob
bery, and on Tuesday, 8th Sept., between 7 and 8 o'clock in the morning, I went to No. 8, Bridge's Place, Shoreditch—I found Brooks and Peach in bed together—I said to Brooks, "I want you for a robbery in Shoreditch, and one in Peckham, where 250l. was stolen"—he said, "I know nothing about the one in Shoreditch;" I told him he must get up and go with me—I commenced searching the room, and found this gold watch and chain—a gold brooch and ring; 2l. in money, and some bills for goods receipted (produced); one for 2l. 19s. and the other for 38l. 8s. 6d.—the bills were in a room down stairs—they are dated 2nd Sept.—I showed them to Brooks, and he said, "They are the bills of the goods"—I took him down stairs—he said, "I suppose I shall be remanded for the Peckham affair; would you let her know where she could come and see me?" pointing to Peach—I produce this cap, which I found in her room two or three days afterwards; also another suit of old clothes, the same suit that he has on now—he was taken be
fore a Magistrate on the same day—Peach came on a subsequent day, and was ordered into custody—I afterwards went with Sergeant Bond to Richardson's, who keeps a little chandler's shop, just by Mint Street, in the Borough—Bond said, "Well, Mrs. Richardson, I want you for being con
cerned with a person, named Brooks, in a robbery at Peckham"—she said, "I know nothing about Brooks"—I went up stairs, and found a savings' bank book—Richardson was brought up—I said, "Is this your's?"—she said, "Yes; that is my money for goods that I have sold that my husband left me when he went away twelve months ago," alluding to 30l. paid into the bank on 7th Sept., as appears by the book—I said, "It is in the name of Ball;" she said, "Yes, that was my maiden name."

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. How many examinations were there before the Magistrate? A. Four—I know nothing about Cocks being charged—I know nothing of what took place before Brooks was taken—I heard Mr. Coleman examined on the 8th—I believe what he said was taken down in writing.
(MR. RIBTON. wished evidence to be given of what was stated on the 8th, it not being returned on the depositions, but the COURT decided that it could not be done.)

Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Q. Did not Richardson tell you that she lived in Union Walk, Kingsland Road? A. Yes, previously to coming to Mint street, and I ascertained that she had lived there—I understood her to say that she did not know Brooks; not that she did not know any
thing of the robbery, but it was Bond that spoke to her—I understood the words so, as I went up stairs—I found that what she said about the furni
ture was not correct—she had no furniture when she left Union Walk—I went there, and they told me that she had none—she had left there a month, but she had been living there twelve months—they did not tell me that she had no furniture twelve months before—I heard her say that she had got the mantle and other goods on tally—I do not know Allen, except

by seeing him now—I do not know whether he is Brooks's brother-in-law—I do not know that he has been three times before convicted—I know nothing about him, and do not know whether Bond does—I first saw him three days before Richardson was apprehended—I do not know that he is a deserter from the East India Company.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Was this a lodging house where you apprehended Brooks? A. A bawdy house—I have seen prostitutes go in and out there—Brooks was living there—the landlady is not here—her name is Levi—I know nothing about Cocks—Mrs. Levi and a man were in bed in the back room, and Peach and Brooks in another room—there was nobody else in the house—there are only two rooms down stairs, and two up—the two down stairs were unoccupied—they are a washhouse and a sitting room—it was about 8 o'clock in the morning when I went there—I am in that division—I see sergeant Bond every day—I know that a policeman was taken up, but I do not know his name—I knew it after the first or second examination of Brooks—I found this cap, three days after Brooks was in custody, up stairs in his room, not in another part of the house, and the clothes were hanging on the wall of the room I found him in bed in—Mrs. Levi took these bills out of a box.

MR. POLAND. Q. Did you find that Richardson had sold any furniture or not? A. They told me she had none—the 30l. in the savings' bank was paid in on 11th Sept.—a constable named Short went with me to Brooks's house.

HENRY SHORT . (Policeman, G 77). On Tuesday morning, 8th Sept, I went with Evans to No. 8, Boyd's Place, Shoreditch—I saw Brooks and Peach there—I assisted Evans in searching the room, and found a gold watch, a pair of bracelets, and a gold pin, in the drawer of a washing stand in the room—Brooks was afterwards taken to the Peckham station, and while there he said, "I do not know where Peckham is; I was never there."

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Do you know anything about a policeman named Cox having been charged with this? A. I heard some
thing about it—I heard it spoken of when I was at Peckham, not before I went to Brooks's house—I do not know Cox.

SARAH LEVI . I am landlady of No. 8, Boyd's Place, Shoreditch. Brooks and Peach lodged with me, as man and wife, seven weeks before the officers came—I gave the constables some papers like these—Brooks had given me those papers to mind, I think on the Friday previous—I said to him, "You are getting on a little better"—he said, "My grandmother is dead, and has left me a little money.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Do you recollect the Tuesday before he was taken? A. Yes, Peach was at home that day, making a dress with me, and the bonnet I have on now—I know it was on a Tuesday, from what I have read in the newspapers—I know that Peach was at home with me that day, instead of being where it has been said she was—she was at home all day with me—we went out in the evening to go to the City of London Theatre, half price; but we joined company with two sailors, and went and had a pot of ale, and then went home—she was never away from me the whole evening, nor the whole of the day—this is the very that she helped me to make.

MR. POLAND. Q. Do you remember the constables coming on the Tues
day morning? A. Yes; Peach was in bed with Brooks—it was the Tuesday before that that Brooks was at home with me—she was not out the whole of the day to my knowledge.

EDWARD SATCH . I am a jeweller, of 172; shoreditch On 2nd Sept., Brooks and Peach came to my shop—I think it was in the afternoon—I sold them these watches, and took 38l. 8s. 6d. of Brooks, all in gold—Peach was present when he paid me—the watches were selected out of the window—he said very little—I had most of the say—he bought one for himself and one for the lady who was with him.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you make an entry of it? A. Yes, in my book—I have not got it here—policeman came to me about two days afterwards to make inquiry—he asked if they were bought of me and when—I did not refer to my book then, because he placed the book be
fore me, and I saw the date—it is the 2nd—it is my writing—I am sure. that is the correct date.

SAMUEL JOHN PIPER . I am foreman to Abraham Limes, a tailor, 168, Shoreditch—on Wednesday, 2nd Sept., Brooks and Peach came there together—I served Brooks with a coat, waistcoat, and trowsers—he paid 2l. 19s. for them—he paid in gold—I gave him 1s. change—here is the bill I gave him.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you make any entry of it in your books? A. I did—I afterwards referred to the entry when the officers came, and found it—it corresponds with the bill.

JOHN BOND . (Police sergeant, P 2). On 8th Sept., I was at the Peckham station, when Brooks was brought there—as I was entering the charge, he said he was innocent of it—I said, "If you are innocent, you can account for this property that was found to be in your possession the day after the robbery"—he said that he had purchased it, and the constable had the receipts—I said, "Yes, but how did you come by the money to purchase it with?"—(I did not, give him any caution before putting these questions not, think
ing I should be examined as a witness)—he said it was money that be had won on a betting transaction, where he had won 40l. odd—I asked him when—he said the Saturday week previous—I asked where—he said he could not tell—I asked from whom he had won it—he said he did not know—I asked him if he could refer me to any one who was present at the time—he said no, he could not—in booking the charge, I asked what he was—he said he was a betting, man, and he got his living by betting at public houses, where skittles and card playing was going on—I was present at the Police Court when Peach was pointed out by the witness Gosling—I have measured the distance from where the Laites live to the King's Head—it is about thirty feet; from wall to wall, I might say from window to window, for I held the string at one end, and Mr. Coleman at the other—I went up into the front room at Laite's house, about 9 o'clock at night—it was a few days, after Brooks was under arrest—by my direction, some one went into the front bed room at the Kings Head, with a caudle—I could see from the one room to the other—I could see the person moving about with the light—I was able to distinguish the features, and I went over to the King's Head and pointed out the man—I did not know who was going up into the room—I told Mr. Coleman to send a stranger, and not to go himself—on Saturday, 7th Oct., I went to Richardson's with the con
stable, Evans—it is a chandler's shop, close by St. George's Church, in the Borough—I found her behind the counter—I told her I had come to apprehend her, for being concerned, with Brooks, and a girl named Peach, in a robbery at a public house at Peckham—she hesitated very much, and I believe she said she did not know any one of the name of Brooks—I asked her if she had not heard that these was

a man named Brooks and a girl named Peach in custody for a robbery at Peckham—she said she had heard of it, but she knew nothing of the robbery—I told her she must consider herself my prisoner, and we should search the house—I asked her if she had any money, or books relating to money, to give up, for what we found we should take away—she said she had none—Evans was then directed to go up stairs—he wanted a key, I handed a key to him, which Richardson took from her pocket—I saw him open a box with it and find a bank book—Richardson said it was her book, and the money was the proceeds of some furniture—she was reminded of the name on the book, and she said she put it in in her maiden name—I found this parasol, which appears to be new, and a shawl up stairs—at the station, a purse containing 11s. was handed to me by the searcher, and some duplicates, and about 9s. I took out of the till in the shop—she said the goods were hers, but the fixtures were not.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Was Cox, the constable, apprehended on 2nd Sept.? A. Yes; he was charged before the Magistrate with this offence; I believe Mr. Coleman gave evidence against him, I was not present—I do not know who was examined—it was from a remark Cox made at a public house that he was taken into custody—he was not on the beat at the time of the robbery, he was at Nunhead—that is half a mile from Mr. Coleman's—he is still in the force; I think he has been in the force not quite twelve months; before that, I think he was a soldier—I heard at the station that he was charged with this, not the same day, it was some few days after—I cannot say what day Cox was charged, I heard it the same day—it was generally mentioned among the police at our place—it was known to all the police in the district—there are no police-men here who were present when the charge was made against Cox—I am not aware of any man named Cook having been examined in this case—I have been nearly fifteen years in the force—I do not know that it is a practice of mine to ask questions of prisoners—I do not know that there is anything wrong in it—I never heard it censured by any of the Judges.

Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Q. Do you know anything of the wit
ness Allen? A. I never saw him until he was at the Police Court—I know nothing of his antecedents—I do not know that he is a deserter from the East India Company, or that he has been three times convicted of felony—I believe a reward of 50l. was offered in this case the day after the robbery, before Brooks was apprehended—Richardson did not at first say that she knew nothing about the robbery, though she had heard something of it, and knew a man named Brooks—she said so afterwards—at first she hesitated, and I believe she said she did not know him, but I would not swear that—there was another shawl found, but I did not take that, as it was older—it was not a red shawl—I do not know what colour it was—I found no 5l. notes.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Were any of the lost notes traced? A. I think three have come into the bank—I have not inquired by whom they were paid in—other officers have—if they had been in any way traced to either of the prisoners, I should have heard of it.
MR. POLAND. Q. I believe Cox was taken before the Magistrate and discharge? A. Yes; he is still in the police force.

JOHN SHORT . I am a butcher, at No. 79, Bethnal Green Road. I know Richardson—about the second week in Sept., she brought me a savings' bank book to take care of—this is it—here is the same entry of 30l. in the

name of Ball—she also asked me to take care of 10l. in gold—about ten days afterwards she fetched them away, saying that she was going to take a chandler's shop, and wanted the money to stock it with next day—I do not know where she was living at the time she brought this.
Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Q. I believe she had dealt with you for a long time? A. Yes, and always behaved fairly and honourably to me.

THOMAS GEORGE ALLEN . I am a leather dresser, of No. 6, East Street, Southwark Bridge Road. I know Peach—I went to Horsemonger Lane Gaol several times to see her—she asked me if I knew a woman named Richardson—I said, "Yes"—she asked me if I knew where she was—I said that I did not—she said, "I wish you did; I have a message I want you to take to her"—I said, "I will try and find out;" and I did so after I left the gaol, and then went back and told her that I had found Richardson's address—she said, "I wish you would go to her, and tell her that I am here, in the place where she ought to be; and if she will not give me money to maintain me during the time I am in this prison, and likewise provide money for Counsel for me, I shall not be quiet; she knows she had a share of the property, and can do it if she likes"—I went to Richardson, who was at a chandler's shop, in Lant Street, in the Borough, and delivered the message to her—she said, "If I did have a share of the property, I made good use of it; I have not been such a fool with it as other people; I shall not give anything"—a day or two after that, I went to the gaol, and told Peach that she would do nothing for her—she told me to go and ask her again, and I went the next day, or the day after, and told her she must give something for Counsel for her, and she gave me 1l. 6s., but said that it was very hard that she should be obliged to give it—I did not go back to Peach, but, by her direction, gave 18s. to Mr. Neale, the solicitor—I had to pay the expenses of the friends of Peach, and we sent her bread and cheese to the prison, and Peach's mother was there, and we went and had tea together, and the expenses were 5s. or 6s.—I went to Richardson two or three days afterwards, and told her that they had not enough for Counsel, and asked her to put her name down on a petition, and she put her name down for 10s. more—on that occasion, Richardson said, "I know I had a box that some portion of the property was in, and I destroyed it as I came along."

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Are you in regular employment? A. Yes; I can write down where it is, but do not feel inclined to tell you, as I think it is an exposure of my master, that is the only objection I have—I have been eight months in his employ; I left through slackness about four weeks ago, and went back to him a fortnight ago—before that I was two mouths with Mr. Cole, a gentleman, in the New Kent Road—I left them through slackness—for twelve months before that I did nothing—my father and my brothers assisted me to live—my father is a leather dresser in the Kent Road—before that I was at the West End of the town for five years, at Ryman and Sons, leather dressers, Mason Street, Soho—I left be
cause I was two days away from work—I was once a soldier in the East India Company's service—I deserted once, not in India, but down in the country at their depot—I enlisted here for the purpose of going out to India—I wanted to take my wife and children, and they would not allow it—I was apprehended for that—I have been at Guildhall twice for having stolen property in my possession—I was tried at the Surrey Sessions and got six months' imprisonment—that was my first offence—it was two years ago, or it might be more—the next was being in company with a bad character, for which I got three months at Lambeth Police Court, summary—that was

very near twelve months ago—I was never in any other trouble—I never turned Queen's evidence—I never gave evidence in a court of justice before—I know nothing about stealing a rifle; I know something about pledging one—some parties were had for that—they were not friends of mine—I was taken up for pledging it, and the others for stealing it—there were two of them—they got four years from this place—I did not give evidence—I was tried with them, and acquitted—my brother pledged it in my name and address-—I had known the man two or three months at shoreditch—I do not know whether the police have offered a reward in this business—I have heard of it since this week or two—it was after I gave evidence against Richardson—I got no money from anybody, and do not expect any—I have had no conversation with Sergeant Bond about it.

Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Q. Have you been in prison three times? A. Yes—the 10s. I got from Richardson I spent for my own expenses—I did not give Peach any of it, nor any of the 8s. which was spent.

MR. POLAND. Q. When you went to the police station, did you give your right name? A. Yes, and my wrong address—I was ordered to attend before the Magistrate; I did not do so, because I thought they would want me as a witness—they found out where 1, lived, and served me with a sum
mons, which brought me here—I paid the 18s. to Mr. Neale, close by the Police Court.
MR. RIBTON. to JOHN COLEMAN. Q. Was your wife examined at the time Cox was at the bar? A. Yes—I never heard the name of Cock in any court or place.

THOMAS RICHARDS . I am a detective officer on the Brighton Railway. I know Richardson—I know that she had no furniture twelve months ago; she was in great distress, and I do not believe she had any to sell—I have known her twelve months last Sept., when I had occasion to go to her house, at No. 7, Union Walk, Union Street, Shoreditch—I know her husband well, but never knew her when she was with him.

PEACH—
NOT GUILTY .

RICHARDSON—
GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

BROOKS—
GUILTY .—He was further charged with having been before convicted: to which he PLEADED GUILTY.—
Six Years Penal Servitude.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, NOVEMBER. 23RD., 1857.
